questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of recurrent pain and swelling near the anterior margin of his right ear. Upon examination, a small opening is noted anterior to the tragus with signs of local infection. His medical history is notable for similar episodes over the past two years, which were managed conservatively. Considering his recurrent symptoms and the chronic nature of the condition, which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.correct_answer: B. Surgical excision of the sinus
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Surgical excision of the sinus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A preauricular sinus is a congenital malformation arising from the improper fusion of the first and second pharyngeal arches, often leading to a small pit or sinus tract located near the front of the ear. Recurrent infections are a common complication of preauricular sinuses.
  • • Option A: Antibiotic therapy and warm compresses are effective for acute infections but do not address the underlying sinus tract that predisposes to recurrent infections. Hence, while useful temporarily, this does not provide a long-term solution for patients with recurrent episodes.
  • • Option A: Antibiotic therapy and warm compresses
  • • Option B: Surgical excision of the sinus is the definitive treatment for preauricular sinus, particularly when recurrent infections occur. This method removes the sinus tract, thus eliminating the source of recurrent infections and the associated symptoms.
  • • Option B: Surgical excision of the sinus
  • • Option C: Topical steroids are generally used to reduce inflammation in various dermatologic conditions but have no role in the management of preauricular sinus infections or the sinus itself.
  • • Option C: Topical steroids
  • • Option D: Observation and reassurance may be appropriate for asymptomatic individuals with a preauricular sinus. However, in the presence of recurrent infections and symptoms, this approach is inadequate as it does not address the ongoing risk of further infections.
  • • Option D: Observation and reassurance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that surgical excision is the definitive treatment for recurrently infected preauricular sinuses.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male rugby player presents to the emergency department after sustaining an injury to his ear during a game. He reports that another player's elbow struck his left ear. On examination, there is notable swelling and discoloration of the auricle, with a fluctuant area suggestive of a collection. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Aspiration of the hematoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A hematoma of the pinna, or auricular hematoma, occurs when blood collects between the cartilage of the ear and its overlying perichondrium. This condition is common in contact sports participants and can lead to cartilage necrosis and deformity of the ear, known as cauliflower ear, if not treated promptly.
  • • Option A: Cold compress and anti-inflammatory medications can reduce swelling and pain but do not address the underlying collection of blood that threatens the integrity of the auricular cartilage.
  • • Option A: Cold compress and anti-inflammatory medications
  • • Option B: Aspiration of the hematoma is the preferred initial management for an auricular hematoma. This intervention involves using a needle to remove the collected blood, relieving pressure from the cartilage and preventing necrosis and deformity.
  • • Option B: Aspiration of the hematoma
  • • Option C: Topical antibiotic ointment may be used to prevent infection at a needle site post-aspiration or incision but does not manage the hematoma itself.
  • • Option C: Topical antibiotic ointment
  • • Option D: Oral antibiotics and observation are not appropriate as initial management. Antibiotics do not address the hematoma, and without intervention, the risk of cartilage necrosis and deformity increases.
  • • Option D: Oral antibiotics and observation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspirate auricular hematomas promptly to prevent cartilage necrosis and the development of cauliflower ear.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes presents with severe right ear pain, purulent otorrhea, and difficulty opening his jaw. Examination reveals granulation tissue in the external auditory canal. There is concern for malignant otitis externa. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Intravenous ceftazidime

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Malignant otitis externa is a severe, potentially life-threatening infection typically caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa , particularly in diabetic or immunocompromised patients. It involves the external auditory canal and can extend to the skull base (osteomyelitis).
  • • Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • • Option A: Oral ciprofloxacin is a reasonable outpatient treatment for uncomplicated cases of acute otitis externa but may not provide adequate coverage or drug levels in severe cases such as malignant otitis externa, where broader and more aggressive intravenous therapy is often required.
  • • Option A: Oral ciprofloxacin
  • • Option B: Intravenous ceftazidime provides effective antipseudomonal coverage and is appropriate for initial management of malignant otitis externa to control the infection, prevent further complications, and manage the systemic aspects of severe infections.
  • • Option B: Intravenous ceftazidime
  • • Option C: Immediate surgical debridement may be necessary in the later stages of treatment or in cases where there is extensive necrosis and failed medical management. However, initial focus should be on aggressive medical management.
  • • Option C: Immediate surgical debridement
  • • Option D: Topical antifungal treatment is not appropriate as Pseudomonas aeruginosa , a bacterium, causes malignant otitis externa. Antifungals do not address the underlying bacterial infection.
  • • Option D: Topical antifungal treatment
  • • Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Administer intravenous antipseu domonal antibiotics as initial treatment for malignant otitis externa to control the infection and prevent complications.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents for evaluation of chronic ear infections. During a detailed otoscopic examination, the physician identifies a retraction pocket in the upper part of the tympanic membrane. This finding raises concern for a potential cholesteatoma. In which area of the middle ear is a cholesteatoma most likely to develop initially due to this retraction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Prussak's space

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Sinus tympani - This is an area located posteriorly in the middle ear, between the ponticulus and subiculum. While cholesteatomas can occur here, it is not the most common initial site for cholesteatoma development related to retraction pockets from the upper part of the tympanic membrane.
  • • Option A: Sinus tympani
  • • Option B: Prussak's space - This space is situated between the scutum and pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane laterally and the neck of the malleus medially. It is the most common site for the initial development of cholesteatoma from retraction pockets, particularly in the scenario described.
  • • Option B: Prussak's space
  • • Option C: Tegmen tympani - This is the bony roof of the middle ear, separating it from the middle cranial fossa. Cholesteatomas in this area are typically a result of extensive spread rather than an initial site of development.
  • • Option C: Tegmen tympani
  • • Option D: Facial recess - Located posteriorly in the middle ear, this area lies between the facial nerve and chorda tympani. Although important surgically, it is not a common initial site for cholesteatoma development related to the described retraction pockets.
  • • Option D: Facial recess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that Prussak’s space is the most common initial site for cholesteatoma development in cases of tympanic membrane retraction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with progressive hearing loss in her right ear, which she has noticed over the past two years. She denies any pain, discharge, or ringing in the ear. Her medical history is unremarkable except for osteogenesis imperfecta. Examination reveals an intact tympanic membrane with no signs of infection. A tuning fork test shows a Rinne negative and Weber lateralizing to the poorer ear. Based on her clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Otosclerosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Meniere's disease typically presents with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. The hearing loss in Meniere's disease is usually sensorineural, not conductive as seen in this patient.
  • • Option A: Meniere's disease
  • • Option B: Otosclerosis is a common cause of progressive conductive hearing loss in young adults, particularly white females. It is often associated with a negative Rinne test (indicating conductive hearing loss) and a Weber test that lateralizes to the affected ear. The association with osteogenesis imperfecta and blue sclera (van der Hoeve syndrome) further supports this diagnosis in the patient.
  • • Option B: Otosclerosis
  • • Option C: Acoustic neuroma generally causes sensorineural hearing loss, often accompanied by symptoms like tinnitus and balance disturbances due to its location affecting the vestibulocochlear nerve.
  • • Option C: Acoustic neuroma
  • • Option D: Chronic otitis media with effusion typically presents with a history of recurrent ear infections, aural fullness, and sometimes otorrhea. The hearing loss is conductive, but the patient's history and lack of infection signs make this diagnosis less likely.
  • • Option D: Chronic otitis media with effusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize otosclerosis as a cause of progressive conductive hearing loss in young adults, particularly when associated with conditions like osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a complaint of a pulsatile, swishing noise in her right ear that is synchronous with her pulse. On examination, a reddish mass is visible through an intact tympanic membrane, and it blanches with increased ear canal pressure. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Glomus tympanicum tumor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Acoustic neuroma typically presents with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance disturbances. It does not cause a visible reddish mass through the tympanic membrane nor exhibit pulsatile tinnitus.
  • • Option A: Acoustic neuroma
  • • Option B: Cholesteatoma is characterized by the presence of a destructive and expanding growth consisting of keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear and/or mastoid process. It might cause hearing loss and discharge but not pulsatile tinnitus or a reddish, blanching mass.
  • • Option B: Cholesteatoma
  • • Option C: Glomus tympanicum tumor is a locally invasive, highly vascular tumor that commonly presents with pulsatile tinnitus and a reddish mass seen through an intact tympanic membrane, as described in this patient. The blanching of the mass with pressure (Brown sign) is indicative of its vascular nature.
  • • Option C: Glomus tympanicum tumor
  • • Option D: Middle ear effusion generally presents with hearing loss and a feeling of ear fullness or pressure. It would show a dull or amber tympanic membrane with reduced mobility, not a reddish mass or pulsatile symptoms.
  • • Option D: Middle ear effusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify glomus tympanicum tumor by its presentation with pulsatile tinnitus and a reddish, blanching mass visible through the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic kidney disease is undergoing treatment for a severe bacterial infection. He has been prescribed an antibiotic known for its ototoxic potential. If he develops ototoxicity, which part of his ear is most likely to be affected first by this medication?

options.label: C
options.text: Outer hair cells of the organ of Corti

questions.correct_answer: C. Outer hair cells of the organ of Corti
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Outer hair cells of the organ of Corti

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Tympanic membrane
  • • Option A: Tympanic membrane
  • • This is incorrect. The tympanic membrane is primarily involved in the transmission of sound vibrations to the ossicles; it is not affected by ototoxic drugs, which primarily target the sensory structures within the cochlea.
  • • Option B: Auditory nerve
  • • Option B: Auditory nerve
  • • While ototoxic drugs can ultimately affect nerve transmission by damaging the sensory cells that the nerve fibers innervate, the initial site of damage is not the nerve itself, but rather the sensory cells within the cochlea.
  • • Option C: Outer hair cells of the organ of Corti
  • • Option C: Outer hair cells of the organ of Corti
  • • This is correct. Many ototoxic drugs, such as aminoglycoside antibiotics and platinum-based chemotherapy agents, primarily damage the outer hair cells of the organ of Corti in the cochlea. This damage impairs the ability of these cells to amplify and fine-tune sound vibrations, leading to hearing loss.
  • • Option D: Eustachian tube
  • • Option D: Eustachian tube
  • • This is incorrect. The Eustachian tube functions to equalize pressure between the middle ear and the atmosphere; it is not directly affected by ototoxic drugs.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that ototoxic drugs primarily damage the outer hair cells of the organ of Corti, leading to sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of episodes of vertigo that occur when she turns her head to the right while lying down. The vertigo lasts for a few seconds and then resolves. She has no other neurological symptoms. The most likely diagnosis based on her presentation is confirmed by which of the following diagnostic maneuvers?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Dix-Hallpike maneuver

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Weber test
  • • Option A: Weber test
  • • This test is used primarily to differentiate between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the midline of the forehead. It is not used to diagnose vertigo or confirm the cause of vertigo symptoms.
  • • Option B: Dix-Hallpike maneuver
  • • Option B: Dix-Hallpike maneuver
  • • This maneuver is specifically designed to diagnose Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV). It involves moving the patient from a sitting to a lying position with the head turned to one side and extended slightly. This test can provoke characteristic nystagmus associated with BPPV, confirming the diagnosis.
  • • Option C: Romberg test
  • • Option C: Romberg test
  • • This test assesses the integrity of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord and proprioception as part of a neurological examination. It is not specific for diagnosing vertigo or BPPV, as it is used to detect different types of ataxia and balance issues.
  • • Option D: Audiometry
  • • Option D: Audiometry
  • • This test measures hearing function and is used to distinguish between types of hearing loss. While important in a comprehensive auditory evaluation, it does not diagnose vertigo or specifically BPPV.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Use the Dix-Hallpike maneuver to diagnose Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV), indicated by the provocation of vertigo and characteristic nystagmus when the patient's head is positioned in specific orientations.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient presents with episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, and tinnitus. These symptoms are often accompanied by a sensation of fullness in her right ear. Based on her clinical presentation, a diagnosis of Meniere's disease is considered. Which of the following treatment options is most appropriate to initially manage her condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Initiate diuretic therapy and recommend low-salt diet.

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate surgical decompression of the cochlear duct.

options.label: D
options.text: Start treatment with oral antiviral medications.

questions.correct_answer: B. Initiate diuretic therapy and recommend low-salt diet.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Initiate diuretic therapy and recommend low-salt diet.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Prescribe oral antibiotics and decongestants
  • • Option A: Prescribe oral antibiotics and decongestants
  • • This choice is inappropriate as antibiotics are used for bacterial infections and decongestants for eustachian tube dysfunction or middle ear effusions, neither of which are indicated in Meniere's disease, which is not caused by bacterial infections or simply blocked tubes.
  • • Option B: Initiate diuretic therapy and recommend low-salt diet
  • • Option B: Initiate diuretic therapy and recommend low-salt diet
  • • This is the correct treatment approach for Meniere's disease. Diuretics and a low-salt diet help reduce the fluid pressure in the inner ear by decreasing the body's retention of fluid, thus potentially alleviating the symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss associated with Meniere's disease.
  • • Option C: Immediate surgical decompression of the cochlear duct
  • • Option C: Immediate surgical decompression of the cochlear duct
  • • While surgical options exist for Meniere's disease, they are generally reserved for cases that do not respond to more conservative management. Initial treatment typically involves less invasive options such as medications and dietary changes.
  • • Option D: Start treatment with oral antiviral medications
  • • Option D: Start treatment with oral antiviral medications
  • • This option is not appropriate as there is no evidence that Meniere's disease is caused by a viral infection. Treatment with antivirals is not indicated.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize that the initial management of Meniere's disease typically involves the use of diuretics and dietary modifications such as a low-salt diet to manage the symptoms effectively.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with progressive hearing loss, vertigo, and intermittent facial weakness. An MRI of the brain is ordered to evaluate for possible causes, focusing on the internal auditory canal. Which anatomical features will the radiologist particularly assess to correlate with the patient's clinical symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: The separation of the facial nerve and the superior vestibular nerve by Bill’s bar.

options.label: B
options.text: The joining of the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves in the internal auditory canal.

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of the trigeminal nerve in the anteroinferior quadrant of the internal auditory canal.

options.label: D
options.text: The division of the cochlear and vestibular nerves by the falciform crest.

questions.correct_answer: A. The separation of the facial nerve and the superior vestibular nerve by Bill’s bar.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. The separation of the facial nerve and the superior vestibular nerve by Bill’s bar.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: The separation of the facial nerve and the superior vestibular nerve by Bill’s bar
  • • Option A: The separation of the facial nerve and the superior vestibular nerve by Bill’s bar
  • • This is correct. In the internal auditory canal, Bill’s bar is a critical anatomical landmark that separates the facial nerve, which occupies the anterosuperior part, from the superior vestibular nerve in the posterosuperior part. Given the patient's symptoms of hearing loss, vertigo, and facial weakness, this area is crucial for detailed examination as it could indicate a pathology affecting these nerves.
  • • Option B: The joining of the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves in the internal auditory canal
  • • Option B: The joining of the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves in the internal auditory canal
  • • This option is incorrect because the glossopharyngeal (IX) and vagus (X) nerves do not travel through the internal auditory canal, nor do they join there. These nerves are associated with the jugular foramen.
  • • Option C: The presence of the trigeminal nerve in the anteroinferior quadrant of the internal auditory canal
  • • Option C: The presence of the trigeminal nerve in the anteroinferior quadrant of the internal auditory canal
  • • This is incorrect. The trigeminal nerve does not pass through the internal auditory canal; it passes through the trigeminal, or Meckel's, cave and exits the brainstem from the pons, not the internal auditory canal.
  • • Option D: The division of the cochlear and vestibular nerves by the falciform crest
  • • Option D: The division of the cochlear and vestibular nerves by the falciform crest
  • • This option is misleading. The falciform crest separates the upper two nerves (facial and superior vestibular) from the lower two (cochlear and inferior vestibular) nerves in the internal auditory canal, not just the cochlear from the vestibular nerves.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the arrangement of nerves within the internal auditory canal, especially the anatomical landmarks such as Bill’s bar and the falciform crest, which are essential for diagnosing pathologies affecting cranial nerves VII and VIII.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents with a gradual onset of unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus. On examination, she has diminished corneal reflex and facial numbness on the same side. An MRI shows a mass in the cerebellopontine angle. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Acoustic neuroma (Vestibular schwannoma)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Meningioma
  • • Option A: Meningioma
  • • Meningiomas can occur in the cerebellopontine angle and might present with similar symptoms due to mass effect. However, the primary symptoms of unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus are more characteristic of acoustic neuroma, which directly affects the cranial nerves associated with auditory functions.
  • • Option B: Acoustic neuroma (Vestibular schwannoma)
  • • Option B: Acoustic neuroma (Vestibular schwannoma)
  • • This is the correct answer. Acoustic neuromas typically arise from the vestibular portion of the eighth cranial nerve and can cause symptoms such as unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and due to their location in the cerebellopontine angle, can also affect the trigeminal nerve (V) leading to facial numbness and a reduced corneal reflex.
  • • Option C: Cholesteatoma
  • • Option C: Cholesteatoma
  • • Cholesteatoma is a benign growth of skin cells in the middle ear or temporal bone that can erode bone and cause hearing loss; however, it does not typically present as a cerebellopontine angle mass on MRI and is not associated with facial numbness or a decreased corneal reflex.
  • • Option D: Metastatic brain tumor
  • • Option D: Metastatic brain tumor
  • • While metastatic tumors can occur in the cerebellopontine angle, the specific presentation of unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, along with imaging findings, is more suggestive of an acoustic neuroma rather than a metastatic lesion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize that acoustic neuroma typically presents with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and may involve other cranial nerves causing symptoms like facial numbness and decreased corneal reflex, particularly when located in the cerebellopontine angle.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the clinic with recurrent episodes of otitis media. Upon examination, his symptoms are attributed to eustachian tube dysfunction. Understanding the anatomy of the eustachian tube is critical for diagnosing and managing this condition. Which of the following statements about the anatomy of the eustachian tube is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The eustachian tube is entirely bony in its structure.

options.label: B
options.text: The eustachian tube forms a 55-degree angle with the vertical plane.

options.label: C
options.text: The narrowest part of the eustachian tube is called the isthmus.

options.label: D
options.text: The eustachian tube is primarily derived from the first pharyngeal arch during embryonic development.

questions.correct_answer: C. The narrowest part of the eustachian tube is called the isthmus.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. The narrowest part of the eustachian tube is called the isthmus.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: The eustachian tube is entirely bony in its structure.
  • • Option A: The eustachian tube is entirely bony in its structure.
  • • This statement is incorrect. The eustachian tube is composed of two parts: the outer one-third is bony, and the inner two-thirds are cartilaginous.
  • • Option B: The eustachian tube forms a 55-degree angle with the vertical plane.
  • • Option B: The eustachian tube forms a 55-degree angle with the vertical plane.
  • • This statement is incorrect. The eustachian tube forms a 45-degree angle with the horizontal plane, not 55-degree angle with vertical. This orientation helps facilitate drainage and ventilation of the middle ear.
  • • Option C: The narrowest part of the eustachian tube is called the isthmus.
  • • Option C: The narrowest part of the eustachian tube is called the isthmus.
  • • This is correct. The isthmus is the narrowest portion of the eustachian tube, located at the junction between the bony and cartilaginous parts. This area is significant clinically as it is often where blockages in the tube can occur, leading to conditions like otitis media.
  • • Option D: The eustachian tube is primarily derived from the first pharyngeal arch during embryonic development.
  • • Option D: The eustachian tube is primarily derived from the first pharyngeal arch during embryonic development.
  • • This statement is incorrect. The eustachian tube develops from the first pharyngeal pouch, not the first pharyngeal arch.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that the eustachian tube is composed of both bony and cartilaginous sections, with the narrowest part called the isthmus, critical for its function and common site for dysfunctions such as blockages.

questions.text: A pediatrician is educating a group of parents about the predisposition of infants to middle ear infections compared to adults. Which anatomical characteristic of the infant's eustachian tube contributes most to this increased risk?

options.label: A
options.text: The infant's eustachian tube is longer than that of an adult.

options.label: B
options.text: The infant's eustachian tube is more vertically oriented compared to adults.

options.label: C
options.text: The lumen of the infant's eustachian tube is narrower than in adults.

options.label: D
options.text: The cartilage in the infant's eustachian tube is more flaccid than in adults.

questions.correct_answer: D. The cartilage in the infant's eustachian tube is more flaccid than in adults.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. The cartilage in the infant's eustachian tube is more flaccid than in adults.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: The infant's eustachian tube is longer than that of an adult.
  • • Option A: The infant's eustachian tube is longer than that of an adult.
  • • This statement is incorrect. The infant’s eustachian tube is actually shorter, measuring about 18 mm in length compared to 36 mm in adults. The shorter length can contribute to easier transmission of pathogens from the nasopharynx to the middle ear but is not the primary reason for increased infections.
  • • Option B: The infant's eustachian tube is more vertically oriented compared to adults.
  • • Option B: The infant's eustachian tube is more vertically oriented compared to adults.
  • • This statement is incorrect. The infant's eustachian tube is more horizontally oriented, with an angle of about 10 degrees with the horizontal, compared to the adult’s 45-degree angle. This horizontal orientation facilitates easier reflux of nasopharyngeal contents into the middle ear but is not the primary focus of this question.
  • • Option C: The lumen of the infant's eustachian tube is narrower than in adults.
  • • Option C: The lumen of the infant's eustachian tube is narrower than in adults.
  • • This statement is incorrect. The lumen of the infant's eustachian tube is actually wider, which theoretically should reduce the risk of blockage. However, other factors like the angle and cartilage properties play a more significant role in infection risk.
  • • Option D: The cartilage in the infant's eustachian tube is more flaccid than in adults.
  • • Option D: The cartilage in the infant's eustachian tube is more flaccid than in adults.
  • • This is the correct answer. The flaccid nature of the cartilage in infants contributes to a lack of structural integrity, allowing the tube to collapse more easily. This can hinder proper ventilation of the middle ear, leading to fluid accumulation and increased risk of infections.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that the flaccid nature of the cartilage in an infant’s eustachian tube contributes significantly to the increased risk of middle ear infections by allowing easier collapse and less effective aeration of the middle ear.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to a high fever and severe pain in his left ear, which started two days ago. The physical examination reveals a red, bulging tympanic membrane with pus visible behind the membrane. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient diagnosed with acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM)?

options.label: D
options.text: Advise nasal decongestants and observe without antibiotics.

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Start broad-spectrum oral antibiotics.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Immediate referral for surgical myringotomy.
  • • Option A: Immediate referral for surgical myringotomy.
  • • While myringotomy can be a treatment for ASOM to relieve pressure and drain pus, it is generally not the first line of management unless there is imminent risk of complications or the condition fails to respond to initial medical management.
  • • Option B: Prescribe high-dose oral antihistamines.
  • • Option B: Prescribe high-dose oral antihistamines.
  • • Antihistamines are generally not recommended in the management of ASOM as they do not address the infection and can thicken secretions, potentially worsening the condition.
  • • Option C: Start broad-spectrum oral antibiotics.
  • • Option C: Start broad-spectrum oral antibiotics.
  • • This is the correct choice. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are indicated in cases of ASOM, particularly in children who present with fever, severe ear pain, and a bulging tympanic membrane indicating likely bacterial infection. Antibiotics such as amoxicillin or, in cases of allergy, an alternative like azithromycin, are typically prescribed.
  • • Option D: Advise nasal decongestants and observe without antibiotics.
  • • Option D: Advise nasal decongestants and observe without antibiotics.
  • • Nasal decongestants may help relieve eustachian tube dysfunction but are not sufficient as sole treatment for ASOM with the symptoms described. Observation without antibiotics is typically reserved for very mild cases or where diagnosis is uncertain, which does not apply here given the clear signs of infection.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Initiate treatment with broad-spectrum oral antibiotics for children presenting with symptoms of acute suppurative otitis media, including fever and a red, bulging tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the clinic due to hearing difficulties in both ears, described by his parents as fluctuating over the past few months. Physical examination shows a dull, retracted tympanic membrane without signs of acute infection. Audiometry confirms a mild conductive hearing loss. The most likely diagnosis is otitis media with effusion (OME). Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Perform bilateral myringotomy with grommet insertion.

options.label: D
options.text: Observe and schedule a follow-up in three months.

questions.correct_answer: D. Observe and schedule a follow-up in three months.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Observe and schedule a follow-up in three months.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Prescribe broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • • Option A: Prescribe broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • • This option is inappropriate as OME is characterized by the presence of non-infected fluid in the middle ear. Antibiotics are not recommended as they do not affect the resolution of the effusion in the absence of acute infection.
  • • Option B: Perform bilateral myringotomy with grommet insertion.
  • • Option B: Perform bilateral myringotomy with grommet insertion.
  • • While myringotomy with grommet insertion is an effective treatment for chronic OME to relieve pressure and improve hearing by draining the fluid, it is typically considered after a period of observation unless the condition is affecting the child's quality of life significantly or there are concerns about speech and language development.
  • • Option C: Administer high-dose oral antihistamines.
  • • Option C: Administer high-dose oral antihistamines.
  • • Antihistamines are generally not recommended in the management of OME as they have not been shown to facilitate the resolution of effusion and can thicken secretions, potentially worsening the condition.
  • • Option D: Observe and schedule a follow-up in three months.
  • • Option D: Observe and schedule a follow-up in three months.
  • • This is the correct choice for initial management in many cases of OME, especially in the absence of acute symptoms. Many cases of OME resolve spontaneously, thus a period of "watchful waiting" is recommended to determine if the fluid resolves on its own.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that the initial management of otitis media with effusion in children often involves a period of observation to allow for possible spontaneous resolution of the effusion before considering surgical interventions.

questions.text: A 15-year-old man presents with a history of hearing loss and occasional tinnitus. Otoscopy reveals a pearly white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in the antero-superior quadrant of the middle ear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Congenital cholesteatoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Acute otitis media
  • • Option A: Acute otitis media
  • • This condition typically presents with rapid onset of ear pain, fever, and a red, bulging tympanic membrane due to infection, not with a pearly white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane.
  • • Option B: Congenital cholesteatoma
  • • Option B: Congenital cholesteatoma
  • • This is the correct answer. Congenital cholesteatoma is characterized by the presence of a pearly white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane, often located in the antero-superior quadrant. It results from epidermal cell rests left over in the middle ear from embryologic development.
  • • Option C: Otitis media with effusion
  • • Option C: Otitis media with effusion
  • • This condition involves the accumulation of fluid in the middle ear without signs of acute infection and typically does not present with a pearly white mass behind the tympanic membrane.
  • • Option D: Secondary acquired cholesteatoma
  • • Option D: Secondary acquired cholesteatoma
  • • This type of cholesteatoma typically occurs due to a pre-existing perforation through which squamous epithelium migrates into the middle ear. The presence of an intact tympanic membrane as described in the scenario is inconsistent with secondary acquired cholesteatoma.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify congenital cholesteatoma by the presence of a pearly white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane, typically in the antero-superior quadrant, suggestive of epidermal cell rests from embryologic development.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of persistent ear discharge and hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals a marginal, posterosuperior tympanic membrane perforation with visible granulations. The discharge is foul-smelling and occasionally blood-stained. Which type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is most consistent with this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Atticoantral CSOM

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Tubotympanic CSOM
  • • Option A: Tubotympanic CSOM
  • • This type, also known as "safe" CSOM, is characterized by a central or subtotal perforation in the pars tensa. The discharge is typically profuse, mucopurulent, and non-foul-smelling, which does not match the foul-smelling, blood-stained discharge seen in the patient.
  • • Option B: Atticoantral CSOM
  • • Option B: Atticoantral CSOM
  • • This is the correct answer. Atticoantral CSOM, often referred to as "unsafe" CSOM, involves erosion of bone and typically arises from a retraction pocket in the attic or a marginal posterosuperior perforation. The presence of granulations, foul-smelling discharge, and the specific location of the perforation in this patient are classic for this type of CSOM.
  • • Option C: Eustachian tube dysfunction
  • • Option C: Eustachian tube dysfunction
  • • While Eustachian tube dysfunction can lead to issues such as barotrauma and otitis media with effusion, it does not cause the persistent, foul-smelling discharge or granulations typical of atticoantral CSOM.
  • • Option D: Acute otitis media
  • • Option D: Acute otitis media
  • • Acute otitis media generally presents with rapid onset of ear pain, fever, and a bulging tympanic membrane, often in the setting of an upper respiratory infection. It does not typically feature the chronic symptoms or bone erosion associated with atticoantral CSOM.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify atticoantral CSOM by its characteristic presentation of a marginal, posterosuperior tympanic membrane perforation with foul-smelling, sometimes blood-stained discharge, and visible granulations, indicating possible bone erosion.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic ear infections is evaluated for a mastoidectomy. He prefers a surgical option that minimizes the need for postoperative care and has a lower risk of disease recurrence. Which type of mastoidectomy is most appropriate for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Canal-wall-up mastoidectomy with routine follow-up cleaning

options.label: B
options.text: Canal-wall-down mastoidectomy with less frequent follow-ups

options.label: C
options.text: Canal-wall-up mastoidectomy with frequent second-look surgeries

options.label: D
options.text: Canal-wall-down mastoidectomy without the need for second-look surgeries

questions.correct_answer: D. Canal-wall-down mastoidectomy without the need for second-look surgeries
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Canal-wall-down mastoidectomy without the need for second-look surgeries

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Canal-wall-up mastoidectomy with routine follow-up cleaning
  • • Option A: Canal-wall-up mastoidectomy with routine follow-up cleaning
  • • This option is incorrect because canal-wall-up mastoidectomy generally does not require routine follow-up cleanings, though it may require second-look surgeries to check for residual or recurrent disease.
  • • Option B: Canal-wall-down mastoidectomy with less frequent follow-ups
  • • Option B: Canal-wall-down mastoidectomy with less frequent follow-ups
  • • This statement is partly correct in that canal-wall-down mastoidectomy typically results in a low rate of recurrence, making less frequent follow-ups possible concerning the recurrence of the disease. However, this type of surgery does create a cavity that may require periodic cleaning by a doctor.
  • • Option C: Canal-wall-up mastoidectomy with frequent second-look surgeries
  • • Option C: Canal-wall-up mastoidectomy with frequent second-look surgeries
  • • This is an accurate representation of canal-wall-up mastoidectomy, which may require second-look surgeries to manage residual or recurrent disease. However, this option does not align with the patient’s preference for minimizing postoperative care and interventions.
  • • Option D: Canal-wall-down mastoidectomy without the need for second-look surgeries
  • • Option D: Canal-wall-down mastoidectomy without the need for second-look surgeries
  • • This is the correct answer. Canal-wall-down mastoidectomy typically has a lower rate of disease recurrence and does not generally require second-look surgeries, making it suitable for a patient who prefers to minimize postoperative procedures. However, it should be noted that this procedure might require occasional cleaning due to the creation of a large cavity.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that canal-wall-down mastoidectomy is preferred for patients who prioritize a lower risk of recurrence and wish to avoid the necessity for second-look surgeries, despite potential needs for periodic cavity cleaning.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with chronic hearing loss and a history of multiple ear infections. Examination reveals the absence of both the malleus and incus, but the stapes is intact. According to Wullstein's classification, which type of tympanoplasty is most appropriate for reconstructing his tympanic membrane?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Type III

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Type I
  • • Option A: Type I
  • • Type I tympanoplasty, also known as myringoplasty, involves the repair of a perforation in the tympanic membrane alone, without addressing ossicular chain damage, which does not apply to this patient since the malleus and incus are absent.
  • • Option B: Type II
  • • Option B: Type II
  • • Type II tympanoplasty involves grafting over the remnant malleus or incus if there is erosion but not complete absence. In this patient’s case, both the malleus and incus are absent, making Type II inappropriate.
  • • Option C: Type III
  • • Option C: Type III
  • • This is the correct answer. Type III tympanoplasty is indicated when both the malleus and incus are absent. The graft is placed directly over the stapes head, which is still present in this patient, to reconstruct the middle ear mechanism and improve hearing.
  • • Option D: Type IV
  • • Option D: Type IV
  • • Type IV tympanoplasty is used when only the footplate of the stapes is present, and the graft is placed between the tympanic membrane and the oval window. Since the stapes head is still intact in this patient, Type IV is not suitable.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify that Type III tympanoplasty is used when both the malleus and incus are absent, and the graft is placed over the stapes head, restoring the ossicular chain continuity and improving hearing.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with deep-seated retro-orbital pain, diplopia, and persistent ear discharge. On examination, there is tenderness over the mastoid region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C: Petrositis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient presents with Gradenigo's triad, which consists of deep-seated retro-orbital pain (due to involvement of the trigeminal nerve - V), diplopia (due to involvement of the abducens nerve - VI), and persistent ear discharge. Additionally, there is tenderness over the mastoid region, suggestive of inflammation of the petrous apex. Given the clinical presentation, the most likely diagnosis is petrositis.
  • • A) Acute otitis media: Acute otitis media typically presents with otalgia, fever, and erythema of the tympanic membrane. It does not typically involve retro-orbital pain or diplopia.
  • • A) Acute otitis media:
  • • B) Mastoiditis: Mastoiditis presents with tenderness and erythema over the mastoid process, often with protrusion of the auricle. While it may cause ear discharge, it does not typically involve retro-orbital pain or diplopia.
  • • B) Mastoiditis:
  • • C) Petrositis: Petrositis involves infection of the petrous apex of the temporal bone, commonly presenting with Gradenigo's triad and tenderness over the mastoid region.
  • • C) Petrositis:
  • • D) Temporal bone fracture: Temporal bone fractures may present with hemotympanum, Battle's sign, or CSF otorrhea/rhinorrhea. While they can lead to infection if the dura is breached, they typically do not present with the classic symptoms of petrositis.
  • • D) Temporal bone fracture:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify the most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with Gradenigo's triad and mastoid tenderness as petrositis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with persistent ear pain, fever, and purulent discharge from the affected ear. On examination, there is tenderness over the mastoid region. Otoscopy reveals a "light house sign" and sagging of the posterior meatal wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C: Mastoiditis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient presents with symptoms and signs consistent with mastoiditis. Mastoiditis typically presents with persistent ear pain, fever, purulent discharge, and tenderness over the mastoid region. Otoscopy may reveal the "light house sign" (erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane) and sagging of the posterior meatal wall. Additionally, the reservoir sign may be positive, indicating immediate refilling of the canal with discharge after cleaning. Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus is the most common causative organism.
  • • A) Otitis externa: Otitis externa typically presents with ear pain exacerbated by manipulation of the pinna or tragus, erythema, and swelling of the external auditory canal. It does not typically involve tenderness over the mastoid region or purulent discharge.
  • • A) Otitis externa:
  • • B) Acute otitis media: Acute otitis media typically presents with otalgia, fever, and erythema of the tympanic membrane. It may be associated with bulging of the tympanic membrane but does not typically involve mastoid tenderness or purulent discharge.
  • • B) Acute otitis media:
  • • C) Mastoiditis: Mastoiditis presents with persistent ear pain, fever, purulent discharge, mastoid tenderness, and characteristic findings on otoscopy such as the "light house sign" and sagging of the posterior meatal wall.
  • • C) Mastoiditis:
  • • D) Cholesteatoma: Cholesteatoma typically presents with conductive hearing loss, foul-smelling otorrhea, and may be associated with complications such as mastoiditis. It does not typically present with the characteristic otoscopic findings described in mastoiditis.
  • • D) Cholesteatoma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify the most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with persistent ear pain, fever, purulent discharge, mastoid tenderness, and characteristic otoscopic findings such as the "light house sign" and sagging of the posterior meatal wall, indicative of mastoiditis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with vertigo and nystagmus exacerbated by changes in head position and pressure in the external auditory canal. On examination, the Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test reveals abnormal findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C: Labyrinthitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient presents with vertigo and nystagmus exacerbated by changes in head position and pressure in the external auditory canal, suggestive of labyrinthitis. Labyrinthitis occurs when disease spreads into the inner ear, leading to inflammation. The Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test may reveal abnormal findings, with a deviation from the normal pattern of nystagmus seen in healthy individuals (COWS - Cold Opposite Warm Same). In labyrinthitis, the pattern of nystagmus may be different from the COWS pattern due to dysfunction of the vestibular system.
  • • A) Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV): BPPV typically presents with brief episodes of vertigo triggered by changes in head position, such as rolling over in bed or looking up. It is characterized by positional nystagmus, typically lasting less than one minute, and is not associated with changes in pressure in the external auditory canal.
  • • A) Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV):
  • • B) Meniere's disease: Meniere's disease presents with recurrent episodes of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. It is not typically associated with changes in pressure in the external auditory canal or abnormal findings on the Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test.
  • • B) Meniere's disease:
  • • C) Labyrinthitis: Labyrinthitis presents with vertigo and nystagmus exacerbated by changes in head position and pressure in the external auditory canal. The Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test may reveal abnormal findings due to dysfunction of the vestibular system.
  • • C) Labyrinthitis:
  • • D) Vestibular neuritis: Vestibular neuritis presents with sudden onset of severe vertigo, typically without hearing loss or tinnitus. It is not typically associated with changes in pressure in the external auditory canal or abnormal findings on the Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test.
  • • D) Vestibular neuritis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify the most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with vertigo and nystagmus exacerbated by changes in head position and pressure in the external auditory canal, with abnormal findings on the Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test indicative of labyrinthitis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with high-grade fever spikes, oedema on the posterior mastoid, and papilloedema. On examination, there is no change in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure with compression of the jugular vein on the affected side, but compression on the normal side increases CSF pressure. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B: Sigmoid sinus thrombosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient presents with symptoms and signs suggestive of sigmoid sinus thrombosis. Sigmoid sinus thrombosis is characterized by high-grade fever spikes, oedema on the posterior mastoid (Greisinger sign), and papilloedema. The Tobey-Ayer test demonstrates increased intracranial tension (ICT), where compression on the affected side jugular vein causes no change in CSF pressure, while compression on the normal side increases CSF pressure. This differentiates it from other causes of raised ICT. Additionally, the delta sign on CT or MRI may be seen in the posterior cranial fossa. Treatment typically involves modified radical mastoidectomy and removal of the thrombus.
  • • A) Temporal bone fracture: Temporal bone fractures may present with hemotympanum, Battle's sign, or CSF otorrhea/rhinorrhea. While they can lead to intracranial complications, they typically do not present with the characteristic features of sigmoid sinus thrombosis.
  • • A) Temporal bone fracture:
  • • B) Sigmoid sinus thrombosis: Sigmoid sinus thrombosis presents with high-grade fever spikes, oedema on the posterior mastoid (Greisinger sign), papilloedema, and abnormal findings on the Tobey-Ayer test indicative of increased intracranial tension.
  • • B) Sigmoid sinus thrombosis:
  • • C) Acute otitis media: Acute otitis media typically presents with otalgia, fever, and erythema of the tympanic membrane. It does not typically involve papilloedema or findings consistent with sigmoid sinus thrombosis.
  • • C) Acute otitis media:
  • • D) Vestibular schwannoma: Vestibular schwannoma typically presents with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo. It is not typically associated with high-grade fever spikes or findings consistent with sigmoid sinus thrombosis.
  • • D) Vestibular schwannoma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify the most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with high-grade fever spikes, oedema on the posterior mastoid, papilloedema, and abnormal findings on the Tobey-Ayer test indicative of increased intracranial tension, suggestive of sigmoid sinus thrombosis.

questions.text: During a mastoidectomy, a surgeon accidentally injures a nerve located on the posterior wall of the middle ear. Which of the following structures is most likely to be affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B:

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The facial nerve is most likely to be affected during a mastoidectomy, as it courses through the posterior wall of the middle ear in its vertical or mastoid segment. This segment of the facial nerve is susceptible to injury during surgical procedures involving the middle ear. The facial nerve supplies the muscles of facial expression and also gives rise to branches such as the nerve to stapedius and the chorda tympani.
  • • A) Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve exits the skull through the jugular foramen and does not pass through the middle ear. It supplies sensory innervation to the posterior one-third of the tongue, the oropharynx, and the tonsils.
  • • A) Glossopharyngeal nerve:
  • • B) Facial nerve: The facial nerve courses through the posterior wall of the middle ear in its vertical or mastoid segment, making it susceptible to injury during mastoidectomy procedures.
  • • B) Facial nerve:
  • • C) Vestibulocochlear nerve: The vestibulocochlear nerve enters the internal auditory canal along with the facial nerve but does not traverse the middle ear. It is responsible for transmitting sensory information for hearing and balance.
  • • C) Vestibulocochlear nerve:
  • • D) Trigeminal nerve: The trigeminal nerve does not pass through the middle ear. It has three main branches: ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular, which innervate sensory structures of the face, including the skin, mucous membranes, and teeth.
  • • D) Trigeminal nerve:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the vulnerability of the facial nerve during mastoidectomy procedures due to its course through the posterior wall of the middle ear in its vertical or mastoid segment.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with difficulty swallowing and a sensation of a lump in his throat. Examination reveals a mass invading the pre-epiglottic space. Which of the following structures forms the upper boundary of the pre-epiglottic space?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Hyoepiglottic ligament

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Epiglottis: The epiglottis forms the posterior boundary of the pre-epiglottic space, but it does not form the upper boundary.
  • • Option A. Epiglottis:
  • • Option B. Thyroid cartilage: The thyroid cartilage is not directly involved in the formation of the pre-epiglottic space.
  • • Option B. Thyroid cartilage:
  • • Option C. Thyrohyoid membrane: The thyrohyoid membrane forms the anterior boundary of the pre-epiglottic space, but it does not form the upper boundary.
  • • Option C. Thyrohyoid membrane:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify the hyoepiglottic ligament as the structure forming the upper boundary of the pre-epiglottic space, which can be invaded by cancers arising in the supraglottis or base of tongue, leading to symptoms of difficulty swallowing and a sensation of a lump in the throat.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic woman presents with sudden onset unilateral facial paralysis. On examination, there is facial asymmetry, epiphora, and hyperacusis. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?

options.label: C
options.text: Facial nerve decompression surgeryBotulinum toxin injection

questions.explanation:
Ans. B: Oral prednisolone and acyclovir

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient presents with sudden onset unilateral facial paralysis consistent with Bell's palsy, the most common cause of facial nerve palsy. Bell's palsy is often idiopathic but is suspected to have a viral etiology, particularly herpes virus. Diabetics are at increased risk due to angiopathy, and pregnant women due to fluid retention. Clinical features include facial asymmetry, epiphora (tearing), and hyperacusis (increased sensitivity to sound) due to loss of stapedial reflex. The drug of choice for Bell's palsy is oral prednisolone and acyclovir to reduce inflammation and address the suspected viral etiology. Topical corticosteroids may not provide sufficient systemic coverage. Facial nerve decompression surgery is considered if medical treatment fails, and botulinum toxin injection is not indicated as initial therapy for Bell's palsy.
  • • A) Topical corticosteroids: Topical corticosteroids may not provide sufficient systemic coverage for Bell's palsy and are not the initial treatment of choice.
  • • A) Topical corticosteroids:
  • • B) Oral prednisolone and acyclovir: Oral prednisolone and acyclovir are the drug of choice for Bell's palsy, aimed at reducing inflammation and addressing the suspected viral etiology.
  • • B) Oral prednisolone and acyclovir:
  • • C) Facial nerve decompression surgery: Facial nerve decompression surgery is considered if medical treatment with corticosteroids and antivirals fails to relieve symptoms.
  • • C) Facial nerve decompression surgery:
  • • D) Botulinum toxin injection: Botulinum toxin injection is not indicated as initial therapy for Bell's palsy and is typically used in specific cases of facial nerve paralysis where selective muscle weakness requires treatment.
  • • D) Botulinum toxin injection:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify the most appropriate initial treatment for Bell's palsy, consisting of oral prednisolone and acyclovir to reduce inflammation and address the suspected viral etiology.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with gradual onset hearing loss. Audiometric evaluation reveals a down-sloping curve with sensorineural hearing loss. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D: Presbycusis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient presents with gradual onset hearing loss consistent with presbycusis, which is age-induced hearing loss. Presbycusis typically manifests as a down-sloping curve on audiogram, indicating high frequency loss. This pattern of sensorineural hearing loss is commonly seen in the elderly population and is managed with hearing aids.
  • • A) Otosclerosis: Otosclerosis typically presents with a dip at 2000Hz on bone conduction curve, which is not consistent with the audiogram findings described in this patient.
  • • A) Otosclerosis:
  • • B) Noise induced hearing loss: Noise induced hearing loss typically presents with a dip at 4000Hz on audiogram, which is not consistent with the audiogram findings described in this patient.
  • • B) Noise induced hearing loss:
  • • C) Congenital hearing loss: Congenital hearing loss, especially in cases of genetic syndromes like Waardenburg syndrome, may present with a "cookie bite" audiogram, characterized by dips in the mid-frequency range, which is not consistent with the audiogram findings described in this patient.
  • • C) Congenital hearing loss:
  • • D) Presbycusis: Presbycusis is age-induced hearing loss that typically presents with a down-sloping curve on audiogram, indicating high frequency loss, which is consistent with the audiogram findings described in this patient.
  • • D) Presbycusis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the audiogram pattern consistent with presbycusis, characterized by a down-sloping curve indicating high frequency sensorineural hearing loss, commonly seen in the elderly population.

questions.text: During a routine hearing assessment, a patient's stapedial reflex is tested. Which of the following best describes the function of the stapedial reflex?

options.label: A
options.text: It enhances hearing sensitivity in response to soft sounds.

options.label: B
options.text: It protects the ear from damage caused by loud sounds.

options.label: C
options.text: It regulates the balance and coordination of head movements.

options.label: D
options.text: It facilitates the transmission of sound waves through the middle ear.

questions.correct_answer: B. It protects the ear from damage caused by loud sounds.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B: It protects the ear from damage caused by loud sounds.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The stapedial reflex serves to protect the ear from damage caused by loud sounds. When exposed to loud noises, the stapedius muscle contracts, stiffening the stapes bone and reducing its movement. This dampens the transmission of sound vibrations to the inner ear, thereby protecting delicate structures like the cochlea from potential damage. The afferent limb of the stapedial reflex is via the VIII cranial nerve (vestibulocochlear nerve), while the efferent limb is through the VII cranial nerve (facial nerve).
  • • A) It enhances hearing sensitivity in response to soft sounds: This statement is incorrect. The stapedial reflex is not involved in enhancing hearing sensitivity to soft sounds but rather in protecting the ear from loud sounds.
  • • A) It enhances hearing sensitivity in response to soft sounds:
  • • B) It protects the ear from damage caused by loud sounds: This statement is correct. The stapedial reflex serves to protect the ear from potential damage caused by exposure to loud noises by stiffening the stapes bone and reducing sound transmission to the inner ear.
  • • B) It protects the ear from damage caused by loud sounds:
  • • C) It regulates the balance and coordination of head movements: This statement is incorrect. The stapedial reflex is primarily involved in auditory protection and does not regulate balance or head movements.
  • • C) It regulates the balance and coordination of head movements:
  • • D) It facilitates the transmission of sound waves through the middle ear: This statement is incorrect. While the stapedial reflex does involve the middle ear, its primary function is to reduce sound transmission in response to loud noises, rather than facilitating it.
  • • D) It facilitates the transmission of sound waves through the middle ear:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the role of the stapedial reflex in protecting the ear from damage caused by loud sounds by stiffening the stapes bone and reducing sound transmission to the inner ear.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a swelling in the neck that increases in size on Valsalva maneuver. Compression of the swelling produces a hissing sound. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Laryngocele

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Thyroglossal duct cyst: Thyroglossal duct cysts typically present as midline neck swellings that move with swallowing or protrusion of the tongue, and they do not typically increase in size on Valsalva maneuver or produce a hissing sound.
  • • Option A. Thyroglossal duct cyst:
  • • Option B. Branchial cleft cyst : Branchial cleft cysts typically present as lateral neck swellings along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and are not associated with changes in size on Valsalva maneuver or a hissing sound on compression.
  • • Option B. Branchial cleft cyst
  • • Option D. Thyroid nodule: Thyroid nodules typically present as solitary or multiple palpable masses in the thyroid gland and are not associated with changes in size on Valsalva maneuver or a hissing sound on compression.
  • • Option D. Thyroid nodule:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the clinical features of laryngocele, including swelling in the neck that increases in size on Valsalva maneuver and produces a hissing sound on compression, which helps distinguish it from other neck masses.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the purpose of newborn screening of hearing using otoacoustic emissions (OAE) and brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA)?

options.label: A
options.text: OAE assesses the integrity of the auditory nerve, while BERA evaluates outer hair cell function.

options.label: B
options.text: OAE evaluates outer hair cell function, while BERA assesses the integrity of the auditory nerve and auditory pathway to the brain.

options.label: C
options.text: OAE and BERA both primarily evaluate the function of the cochlear nerve.

options.label: D
options.text: OAE and BERA are subjective tests used to assess the responses of newborns to sound stimuli.

questions.correct_answer: B. OAE evaluates outer hair cell function, while BERA assesses the integrity of the auditory nerve and auditory pathway to the brain.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B: OAE evaluates outer hair cell function, while BERA assesses the integrity of the auditory nerve and auditory pathway to the brain.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B is correct. Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) evaluate the function of outer hair cells in the cochlea, while brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) assesses the integrity of the auditory nerve and auditory pathway to the brain. Therefore, normal OAE and BERA results indicate almost normal hearing pathway and are used in newborn screening.
  • • Option A is incorrect. OAE specifically evaluates outer hair cell function, while BERA assesses the integrity of the entire auditory pathway, including the auditory nerve and brainstem.
  • • Option A is incorrect.
  • • Option C is incorrect. While both OAE and BERA are involved in assessing hearing, OAE evaluates outer hair cell function, whereas BERA evaluates the auditory nerve and auditory pathway to the brain.
  • • Option C is incorrect.
  • • Option D is incorrect. OAE and BERA are objective tests that do not rely on subjective responses from the patient. They provide objective measurements of auditory function.
  • • Option D is incorrect.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the purpose of newborn screening of hearing using otoacoustic emissions (OAE) and brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA), where OAE evaluates outer hair cell function and BERA assesses the integrity of the auditory nerve and auditory pathway to the brain.

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with congenital hearing loss. Imaging studies reveal complete absence of both bony and membranous labyrinth. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D: Michel aplasia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • D) Michel aplasia is the most likely diagnosis in this case . Michel aplasia is characterized by the complete absence of both bony and membranous labyrinth, resulting in profound congenital hearing loss.
  • • D) Michel aplasia is the most likely diagnosis in this case
  • • A) Schiebe dysplasia: Schiebe dysplasia involves cochlea and saccule dysplasia, but it does not present with complete absence of the bony and membranous labyrinth as seen in this case.
  • • A) Schiebe dysplasia:
  • • B) Alexander dysplasia: Alexander dysplasia affects the basal turn of the cochlea, but it does not result in complete absence of the labyrinth.
  • • B) Alexander dysplasia:
  • • C) Bing-Seibenmann dysplasia: Bing-Seibenmann dysplasia is characterized by the complete absence of the membranous labyrinth, but it does not involve the absence of the bony labyrinth, as seen in this case.
  • • C) Bing-Seibenmann dysplasia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify Michel aplasia as the condition characterized by the complete absence of both bony and membranous labyrinth, leading to congenital hearing loss.

questions.text: During surgery on the larynx, damage to which nerve is most likely to affect the motor function of all intrinsic laryngeal muscles except the cricothyroid muscle?

options.label: B
options.text: External branch of superior laryngeal nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Recurrent laryngeal nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. External branch of superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN) supplies the cricothyroid muscle, which is responsible for tensioning the vocal cords during phonation. Damage to the EBSLN would affect the function of the cricothyroid muscle but not the other intrinsic laryngeal muscles.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve (IBSLN) supplies sensory innervation to the mucosa above the level of the vocal cords. Damage to the IBSLN would result in sensory deficits but would not affect motor function.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve does not innervate the laryngeal muscles; instead, it supplies motor and sensory innervation to structures in the oropharynx and posterior tongue.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify the recurrent laryngeal nerve as the primary motor nerve responsible for innervating all intrinsic laryngeal muscles except the cricothyroid muscle, knowledge critical for preventing complications during laryngeal surgery.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with congenital cochlear malformation and auditory nerve spectrum disorder. Which of the following interventions is most suitable for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C: Auditory brainstem implant (ABSI)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • C) Auditory brainstem implant (ABSI) is the most suitable intervention for a patient with congenital cochlear malformation and auditory nerve spectrum disorder. ABSI is indicated when the cochlea and/or auditory nerve are abnormal. It involves implanting a device directly over the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle to stimulate the brainstem and bypass the defective cochlear and auditory nerve pathways.
  • • C) Auditory brainstem implant (ABSI)
  • • A) Hearing aids: Hearing aids may not be effective for patients with congenital cochlear malformations and auditory nerve spectrum disorders, as these conditions typically involve structural abnormalities that cannot be adequately addressed by hearing aids alone.
  • • A) Hearing aids:
  • • B) Cochlear implant: Cochlear implantation is typically indicated for individuals with intact cochleae and auditory nerves, but with severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss. It may not be suitable for patients with congenital cochlear malformations and auditory nerve spectrum disorders, as the anatomy of the cochlea and auditory nerve may be abnormal.
  • • B) Cochlear implant:
  • • D) Vestibular schwannoma excision: Vestibular schwannoma excision is not indicated for congenital cochlear malformations and auditory nerve spectrum disorders. This procedure is performed to remove benign tumors of the vestibular nerve (acoustic neuromas), which may cause hearing loss, but it is not the appropriate intervention for congenital malformations of the cochlea and auditory nerve.
  • • D) Vestibular schwannoma excision:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify auditory brainstem implant (ABSI) as the most suitable intervention for patients with congenital cochlear malformations and auditory nerve spectrum disorders, involving implantation of a device over the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle to stimulate the brainstem.

questions.text: During thyroid surgery, a surgeon inadvertently damages a nerve that hooks around the subclavian artery on the right side. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected?

options.label: B
options.text: External branch of superior laryngeal nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Recurrent laryngeal nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. External branch of superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN) is not as likely to be affected during thyroid surgery. While it may be encountered during dissection, damage to the EBSLN typically results in weakness or paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle, which is responsible for tensioning the vocal cords, rather than hoarseness or loss of voice.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve (IBSLN) supplies sensory innervation to the mucosa above the level of the vocal cords and is not typically at risk during thyroid surgery.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Phrenic nerve innervates the diaphragm and is not directly involved in thyroid surgery. Damage to the phrenic nerve would result in paralysis of the diaphragm and difficulty breathing, rather than voice changes.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the anatomical course of the recurrent laryngeal nerve and its vulnerability during thyroid surgery, critical for avoiding complications such as hoarseness or loss of voice.

questions.text: A patient presents with breathy voice following a surgical procedure on the neck. Examination reveals unilateral paralysis of both the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) and the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN). Which of the following best describes the mechanism underlying the patient's voice change?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperadduction of the paralyzed vocal cord

options.label: B
options.text: Hypoadduction of the paralyzed vocal cord

options.label: C
options.text: Overcompensation of the unaffected vocal cord

options.label: D
options.text: Undercompensation of the unaffected vocal cord

questions.correct_answer: D. Undercompensation of the unaffected vocal cord
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Undercompensation of the unaffected vocal cord

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hyperadduction of the paralyzed vocal cord is not characteristic of unilateral RLN and SLN palsy. In fact, the paralyzed vocal cord is typically hypoadducted due to paralysis of the intrinsic laryngeal muscles.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Hypoadduction of the paralyzed vocal cord is a characteristic finding in unilateral RLN and SLN palsy, but it does not fully explain the mechanism underlying the breathy voice.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Overcompensation of the unaffected vocal cord is not observed in unilateral RLN and SLN palsy. Instead, the unaffected vocal cord is unable to compensate adequately for the paralyzed vocal cord, leading to undercompensation and a breathy voice.
  • • Option C.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize that unilateral paralysis of both the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) and the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) results in undercompensation of the unaffected vocal cord, leading to a breathy voice that requires medialization for improvement.

questions.text: A patient presents with acute onset of stridor and respiratory distress. Examination reveals bilateral paralysis of the recurrent laryngeal nerves. Which of the following best describes the mechanism underlying the patient's airway obstruction?
questions.correct_answer: B. Hyperadduction of the vocal cords
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Hyperadduction of the vocal cords

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hypoadduction of the vocal cords is not characteristic of bilateral RLN palsy. Instead, hyperadduction occurs due to the unopposed action of the cricothyroid muscles.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option C. Medialization of the vocal cords is not the primary mechanism underlying airway obstruction in bilateral RLN palsy. The vocal cords come to lie in the median position due to paralysis of the intrinsic laryngeal muscles, but the main issue is hyperadduction rather than medialization.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Lateralization of the vocal cords is not a feature of bilateral RLN palsy. Instead, the vocal cords tend to lie in the median position or slightly paramedian due to the loss of function of the intrinsic laryngeal muscles.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize that bilateral paralysis of the recurrent laryngeal nerves leads to hyperadduction of the vocal cords due to the unopposed action of the cricothyroid muscles, resulting in life-threatening airway obstruction requiring emergency airway management.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with a persistent high-pitched, childish voice despite the development of secondary sexual characteristics. Which of the following tests would most likely confirm the diagnosis of puberphonia?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A. Gutzmann pressure test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Barium swallow is not indicated for the diagnosis of puberphonia. It is a radiographic test used to evaluate swallowing disorders, such as dysphagia.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Flexible laryngoscopy may show normal vocal cord mobility but does not specifically confirm the diagnosis of puberphonia.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Audiometry is not indicated for the diagnosis of puberphonia. It is a test used to assess hearing function.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize that the Gutzmann pressure test is a diagnostic tool used to confirm the diagnosis of puberphonia by inducing a change in voice quality from high-pitched to low-pitched.

questions.text: A 40-year-old teacher presents with complaints of hoarseness of voice. Laryngoscopy reveals bilateral lesions at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cords. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Vocal nodules

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Vocal polyps typically present as exophytic, unilateral lesions with thin mucosa. Although they can occur at the same site as vocal nodules, they are more commonly unilateral and pedunculated. Patients with vocal polyps may experience hoarseness of voice and diplophonia (double voice). Treatment involves microlaryngeal surgery followed by speech therapy.
  • • Option B.
