  • • Option C. Vocal cysts are fluid-filled lesions that can occur anywhere along the vocal cords. They typically present as unilateral masses and may cause hoarseness of voice. Treatment usually involves surgical excision.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Reinke's edema, also known as polypoid degeneration, is characterized by diffuse swelling of the subepithelial layer of the vocal cords, resulting in a gelatinous appearance. It is typically seen in individuals with chronic exposure to irritants such as smoking. Patients with Reinke's edema often present with a deep, hoarse voice. Treatment involves cessation of smoking and surgical intervention if necessary.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the clinical features and management of vocal nodules, which commonly present as bilateral lesions at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cords in individuals who use their voice extensively.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with bilateral swelling of the neck, difficulty eating, and speaking. Examination reveals cellulitis involving the submandibular space. Which condition is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C: Ludwig's angina

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Peritonsillar abscess: Peritonsillar abscess presents with unilateral swelling and pain in the region of the tonsil. It is characterized by severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a "hot potato" voice. The involvement of the submandibular space is not typical for peritonsillar abscess.
  • • Option A. Peritonsillar abscess:
  • • Option B. Retropharyngeal abscess: Retropharyngeal abscess typically presents with neck stiffness, dysphagia, and odynophagia. It is more common in children and is often associated with recent upper respiratory tract infections. The involvement of the submandibular space is not typical for retropharyngeal abscess.
  • • Option B. Retropharyngeal abscess:
  • • Option D. Parotitis: Parotitis presents with unilateral swelling and tenderness in the region of the parotid gland. It is typically associated with pain during chewing and may be accompanied by fever. The involvement of the submandibular space is not typical for parotitis.
  • • Option D. Parotitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ludwig's angina is characterized by cellulitis involving the submandibular space, which presents with bilateral swelling of the neck, difficulty eating, and speaking, commonly caused by dental infections.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male smoker presents with hoarseness of voice. Laryngoscopy reveals a diffuse collection of edema fluid in the sub-epithelial space, resulting in a saddle-bag appearance of the vocal cords. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Reinke's edema

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Vocal fold granuloma is an inflammatory tissue arising from the perichondrium near the arytenoid cartilage. It is classically seen after endotracheal intubation and can present with symptoms such as globus sensation, dysphonia, and/or odynophonia. Treatment involves surgery if malignancy or infection is suspected or if nonsurgical options have been exhausted.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Leukoplakia, also known as keratosis, is characterized by epithelial hyperplasia with excess keratin deposition, leading to white plaques or warty growths. It is considered a pre-cancerous condition and can present with hoarseness of voice. Diagnosis is confirmed by laryngoscopy, and surgical excision is the treatment of choice.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Vocal nodules are bilateral lesions commonly seen in individuals who use their voice extensively, such as teachers and singers. They typically present at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cords and result from trauma leading to submucosal edema, hemorrhage, and subsequent fibrosis. Patients with vocal nodules complain of hoarseness of voice, and treatment includes voice rest, speech therapy, and microlaryngeal surgery if symptoms persist.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the clinical features and management of Reinke's edema, a condition characterized by a diffuse collection of edema fluid in the sub-epithelial space of the vocal cords, commonly seen in smokers and presenting with hoarseness of voice.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a "hot potato" voice. On examination, the tonsil is found pushed medially. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C: Peritonsillar abscess

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Ludwig's angina: Ludwig's angina presents with bilateral swelling of the neck, difficulty eating, and speaking, often involving the submandibular space. It is commonly caused by dental infections and does not typically present with a "hot potato" voice.
  • • Option A. Ludwig's angina:
  • • Option B. Retropharyngeal abscess: Retropharyngeal abscess typically presents with neck stiffness, dysphagia, and odynophagia. It is more common in children and is often associated with recent upper respiratory tract infections. It does not typically present with a "hot potato" voice.
  • • Option B. Retropharyngeal abscess:
  • • Option D. Parotitis: Parotitis presents with unilateral swelling and tenderness in the region of the parotid gland. It is typically associated with pain during chewing and may be accompanied by fever. It does not typically present with a "hot potato" voice.
  • • Option D. Parotitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peritonsillar abscess presents with severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a "hot potato" voice, with the tonsil found pushed medially on examination due to the collection of pus in the peritonsillar space.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy, nasal obstruction, and unilateral hearing loss. Examination reveals a mass in the nasopharynx. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Acute otitis media: Acute otitis media typically presents with ear pain, fever, and conductive hearing loss. It is caused by inflammation and infection of the middle ear, often secondary to upper respiratory tract infections. It does not typically present with painless cervical lymphadenopathy or nasal obstruction.
  • • Option B. Acute otitis media:
  • • Option C. Chronic sinusitis: Chronic sinusitis may present with nasal obstruction and facial pain or pressure, but it does not typically cause painless cervical lymphadenopathy or unilateral hearing loss. It is characterized by persistent inflammation of the sinuses lasting for at least 12 weeks.
  • • Option C. Chronic sinusitis:
  • • Option D. Nasal polyps: Nasal polyps may cause nasal obstruction and a decreased sense of smell, but they do not typically present with painless cervical lymphadenopathy or unilateral hearing loss. Nasal polyps are noncancerous growths that develop in the lining of the nose or sinuses.
  • • Option D. Nasal polyps:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nasopharyngeal carcinoma typically presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy, nasal obstruction, and unilateral hearing loss, with examination findings including a mass in the nasopharynx.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with sudden onset high-grade fever, dyspnea, and inspiratory stridor. On examination, the child is sitting in a tripod position, and there is redness and swelling of the epiglottis visible behind the base of the tongue. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Antibiotics and steroids

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Intravenous fluids and observation alone would not address the underlying infection and airway compromise associated with acute epiglottitis. Immediate intervention with antibiotics and steroids is necessary to prevent progression to respiratory distress.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Immediate intubation may be required if there is severe respiratory distress or impending airway obstruction. However, the first-line approach is to administer antibiotics and steroids to reduce inflammation and prevent further airway compromise.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option D. Humidification and supportive care are important components of management but should be supplemented with antibiotics and steroids to address the underlying infection and inflammation.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the clinical presentation of acute epiglottitis, characterized by sudden onset high-grade fever, dyspnea, inspiratory stridor, and the tripod sign, and understand that the most appropriate initial management includes antibiotics targeting the causative organism and steroids to reduce epiglottic edema.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with profuse epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and a red, fleshy mass seen in the nasal cavity. Imaging shows bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus anteriorly. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma typically presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy, nasal obstruction, and unilateral hearing loss. It may cause diplopia, ophthalmoplegia, and exophthalmos if it extends into the orbit. However, it does not typically present with profuse epistaxis or a red, fleshy mass in the nasal cavity.
  • • Option A. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:
  • • Option B. Nasal polyps: Nasal polyps may cause nasal obstruction and a decreased sense of smell, but they do not typically present with profuse epistaxis or a red, fleshy mass in the nasal cavity. Nasal polyps are noncancerous growths that develop in the lining of the nose or sinuses.
  • • Option B. Nasal polyps:
  • • Option D. Chronic sinusitis: Chronic sinusitis may present with nasal obstruction and facial pain or pressure, but it does not typically present with profuse epistaxis or a red, fleshy mass in the nasal cavity. Chronic sinusitis is characterized by persistent inflammation of the sinuses lasting for at least 12 weeks.
  • • Option D. Chronic sinusitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma typically presents in adolescent males with profuse epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and a red, fleshy mass in the nasal cavity, and it can extend laterally into the pterygopalatine fossa, causing bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus anteriorly.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male presents with gradual onset fever, hoarseness, and a barking cough. Physical examination reveals inspiratory stridor and intercostal recession. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Croup (Acute laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute bronchiolitis typically presents with wheezing, tachypnea, and respiratory distress, especially in infants. While inspiratory stridor may occur in severe cases, the barking cough and characteristic findings such as hoarseness and intercostal recession are more consistent with croup.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B . Acute epiglottitis is characterized by sudden onset high-grade fever, dyspnea, inspiratory stridor, and a red, swollen epiglottis visible on examination. However, unlike croup, acute epiglottitis is considered a medical emergency and requires immediate intervention with antibiotics and possible airway management, such as intubation or tracheostomy.
  • • Option B
  • • Option D. Bronchial asthma typically presents with recurrent episodes of wheezing, dyspnea, and cough, often triggered by allergens or irritants. Inspiratory stridor and intercostal recession are not typical features of asthma, making croup a more likely diagnosis in this case.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the clinical presentation of croup, including gradual onset fever, hoarseness, barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and intercostal recession, and understand the appropriate management strategies for this condition, which include supportive measures and, in severe cases, airway management.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with chronic tonsillitis characterized by congested anterior pillars and the presence of cheesy material on squeezing the tonsil. Enlarged jugulo-digastric lymph nodes are also noted. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B: Tonsillectomy.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic tonsillitis characterized by congested anterior pillars, Irwin-Moore sign (exudation of cheesy material on squeezing tonsil), and enlarged jugulo-digastric lymph nodes is best managed with tonsillectomy, especially when symptoms are unresponsive to medical therapy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with fever, sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and earache. On examination, red and enlarged tonsils are observed. Yellowish spots are noted on the tonsil crypts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B: Acute tonsillitis.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Chronic tonsillitis: Chronic tonsillitis typically presents with persistent or recurrent inflammation of the tonsils over a prolonged period. While redness and enlargement of the tonsils may be present, the acute onset of symptoms such as fever and sore throat, along with the presence of yellowish spots on the tonsil crypts, suggests an acute rather than chronic process.
  • • Option A. Chronic tonsillitis:
  • • Option C. Peritonsillar abscess: Peritonsillar abscess presents with severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, trismus, and a characteristic "hot potato" voice due to the accumulation of pus in the peritonsillar space. While acute tonsillitis can progress to peritonsillar abscess if left untreated, the presence of yellowish spots on the tonsil crypts suggests a milder form of acute inflammation rather than an abscess.
  • • Option C. Peritonsillar abscess:
  • • Option D. Tonsillar carcinoma : Tonsillar carcinoma typically presents with persistent symptoms such as sore throat, difficulty swallowing, earache, and possibly a painless neck mass. It is less likely in a young patient presenting with acute symptoms of tonsillitis.
  • • Option D. Tonsillar carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute tonsillitis typically presents with sudden onset symptoms of fever, sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and earache, along with red and enlarged tonsils. Yellowish spots on the tonsil crypts may be indicative of follicular tonsillitis, with group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus being a common causative organism.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with difficulty swallowing, inspiratory stridor, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Examination reveals a greyish-white pseudomembrane in the oropharynx that bleeds on removal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C. Laryngeal diphtheria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Croup (Acute laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis) presents with symptoms such as gradual onset fever, hoarseness, barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and intercostal recession. While cervical lymphadenopathy may be present in croup, the characteristic greyish-white pseudomembrane seen in diphtheria is not typical.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Acute epiglottitis is characterized by sudden onset high-grade fever, dyspnea, inspiratory stridor, and a red, swollen epiglottis visible on examination. While both acute epiglottitis and laryngeal diphtheria can cause airway obstruction, the presence of a greyish-white pseudomembrane is more suggestive of diphtheria.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option D. Retropharyngeal abscess typically presents with symptoms such as fever, neck stiffness, dysphagia, and odynophagia. While airway obstruction can occur due to compression of the airway by the abscess, the characteristic pseudomembrane seen in diphtheria is not present in retropharyngeal abscess.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the clinical features of laryngeal diphtheria, including the formation of a greyish-white pseudomembrane in the oropharynx, cervical lymphadenopathy, and airway obstruction, and understand the appropriate management strategies for this condition, which include administration of diphtheria antitoxin, antibiotics, and airway maintenance.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and snoring. On examination, the child exhibits a high arched palate, crowded teeth, and a pinched-up nose. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C:  Adenoid hypertrophy.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Chronic rhinosinusitis: Chronic rhinosinusitis typically presents with symptoms such as nasal congestion, facial pain, and postnasal drip, but it is less likely to cause mouth breathing, snoring, high arched palate, and crowded teeth, which are characteristic features of adenoid hypertrophy.
  • • Option A. Chronic rhinosinusitis:
  • • Option B. Tonsillitis: Tonsillitis primarily affects the palatine tonsils and presents with symptoms such as sore throat, fever, and difficulty swallowing. While tonsillitis can contribute to mouth breathing, it is less likely to cause snoring and the facial changes associated with adenoid hypertrophy
  • • Option B. Tonsillitis:
  • • Option. D. Nasal polyps: Nasal polyps are soft, noncancerous growths that develop in the lining of the nasal passages or sinuses. While they can cause nasal obstruction and mouth breathing, they are less likely to lead to snoring or the characteristic facial changes seen in adenoid hypertrophy.
  • • Option. D. Nasal polyps:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenoid hypertrophy is characterized by nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, snoring, and associated facial changes such as a high arched palate, crowded teeth, and a pinched-up nose, known as adenoid facies. Diagnosis is confirmed by lateral X-ray of the nasopharynx.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with voice fatigue and painful phonation. Examination reveals a mouse-nibbled appearance of the vocal cords and a turban epiglottis. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Tuberculosis of larynx

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Vocal nodules typically present with hoarseness of voice and are characterized by bilateral, sessile lesions at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cords. While vocal nodules can cause voice fatigue, the characteristic findings described in the scenario, such as a mouse-nibbled appearance and turban epiglottis, are not consistent with vocal nodules.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Acute epiglottitis presents with sudden onset high-grade fever, dyspnea, and inspiratory stridor due to airway obstruction caused by a swollen epiglottis. While both acute epiglottitis and tuberculosis of the larynx can cause voice fatigue, the characteristic findings described in the scenario, such as a mouse-nibbled appearance and turban epiglottis, are not typical of acute epiglottitis.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C . Laryngeal diphtheria is characterized by the formation of a greyish-white pseudomembrane in the oropharynx and larynx, which bleeds on removal. While cervical lymphadenopathy may be present, the characteristic findings described in the scenario, such as a mouse-nibbled appearance and turban epiglottis, are not consistent with laryngeal diphtheria.
  • • Option C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the clinical features of tuberculosis of the larynx, including characteristic findings such as a mouse-nibbled appearance of the vocal cords and a turban epiglottis, and understand the appropriate diagnostic and treatment modalities for this condition, which include biopsy confirmation and antitubercular therapy.

questions.text: A patient presents with a bulge behind the posterior pillar of the oropharynx. Which anatomical space is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C: Parapharyngeal space.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Submandibular space: The submandibular space is located inferior to the mandible and contains the submandibular gland, lymph nodes, and facial artery. Pathologies in this space typically present with swelling in the submandibular region rather than behind the posterior pillar of the oropharynx.
  • • Option A. Submandibular space:
  • • Option B. Sublingual space: The sublingual space is located beneath the tongue and contains the sublingual gland and ducts. Pathologies in this space can cause swelling under the tongue but are less likely to manifest as a bulge behind the posterior pillar of the oropharynx.
  • • Option B. Sublingual space:
  • • Option D. Buccal space: The buccal space is located in the cheek region and contains the buccinator muscle and branches of the facial nerve. Pathologies in this space typically present with swelling in the cheek rather than behind the posterior pillar of the oropharynx.
  • • Option D. Buccal space:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pathologies affecting the parapharyngeal space can manifest as a bulge behind the posterior pillar of the oropharynx due to medial displacement of the pharynx.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is NOT a part of the hypopharynx?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D: Oropharynx

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Posterior pharyngeal wall: This is one of the components of the hypopharynx and forms the posterior boundary of the pharynx.
  • • Option A. Posterior pharyngeal wall:
  • • Option B. Pyriform sinus: The pyriform sinuses are two pear-shaped recesses located on either side of the larynx, and they are considered part of the hypopharynx.
  • • Option B. Pyriform sinus:
  • • Option C. Post-cricoid area: The post-cricoid area is also a component of the hypopharynx, situated below the cricoid cartilage of the larynx.
  • • Option C. Post-cricoid area:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the anatomical components of the hypopharynx, including the posterior pharyngeal wall, pyriform sinus, and post-cricoid area, is essential for assessing and managing conditions affecting this region.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with inspiratory stridor and cyanosis. The stridor increases on crying and improves when the infant is placed in the prone position. Physical examination reveals an omega-shaped epiglottis, floppy aryepiglottic folds, and prominent arytenoids. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C. Laryngomalacia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute epiglottitis typically presents with sudden onset high-grade fever, dyspnea, and inspiratory stridor due to airway obstruction caused by a swollen epiglottis. While inspiratory stridor and cyanosis may be present in both acute epiglottitis and laryngomalacia, the characteristic findings described in the scenario, such as an omega-shaped epiglottis and floppy AEF, are not consistent with acute epiglottitis.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) is characterized by a barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and hoarseness. While both laryngomalacia and croup can cause inspiratory stridor, the characteristic findings described in the scenario, such as an omega-shaped epiglottis and floppy AEF, are not typical of croup.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option D. Tracheomalacia is characterized by excessive collapsibility of the trachea during expiration, leading to expiratory wheezing and respiratory distress. While tracheomalacia can cause respiratory symptoms similar to laryngomalacia, the characteristic findings described in the scenario, such as an omega-shaped epiglottis and floppy AEF, are not consistent with tracheomalacia.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the clinical features of laryngomalacia, including inspiratory stridor that worsens with crying, characteristic physical findings such as an omega-shaped epiglottis and floppy aryepiglottic folds, and understand the management approach, which typically involves observation and may include supraglottoplasty if symptoms persist beyond 2 years of age.

questions.text: Which part of the pharynx lies opposite the C2 and upper C3 vertebrae?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B: Oropharynx

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Nasopharynx: The nasopharynx is situated behind the nasal cavity, extending from the skull base to the soft palate, and lies opposite the C1 vertebra.
  • • Option A. Nasopharynx:
  • • Option C. Laryngopharynx: The laryngopharynx, also known as the hypopharynx, is located behind the larynx, extending from the hyoid bone to the cricoid lower border. It lies opposite the C3-C6 vertebrae.
  • • Option C. Laryngopharynx:
  • • Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as the correct answer is option B. The oropharynx is the part of the pharynx that corresponds to the C2 and upper C3 vertebrae.
  • • Option D. None of the above:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the anatomical divisions of the pharynx and their corresponding vertebral levels is important for clinical assessment and localization of lesions or abnormalities within the pharyngeal region.

questions.text: Which anatomical structure passes through the gap between the middle and superior constrictors of the pharynx?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B: Stylopharyngeus muscle

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Eustachian tube: The Eustachian tube, tensor veli palatini muscle, levator veli palatini muscle, and ascending palatine artery are located within the sinus of Morgagni, which is the gap between the skull base and superior constrictor.
  • • Option A. Eustachian tube:
  • • Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve and inferior laryngeal vessels pass through the gap between the inferior constrictor and the esophagus.
  • • Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve:
  • • Option D. Tensor veli palatini muscle: The tensor veli palatini muscle is also located within the sinus of Morgagni, along with the Eustachian tube.
  • • Option D. Tensor veli palatini muscle:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the anatomical relationships and structures passing through the various gaps between the pharyngeal constrictor muscles aids in clinical assessment and management of conditions affecting the pharynx and adjacent structures.

questions.text: A newborn presents with stridor and respiratory distress shortly after birth. Examination reveals abnormal cricoid thickening, and imaging confirms a subglottic diameter of less than 4mm. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Tracheostomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Conservative management alone is not typically sufficient for congenital subglottic stenosis, especially in cases of severe obstruction requiring immediate intervention to maintain adequate ventilation.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Endoscopic dilatation may be considered for mild cases of congenital subglottic stenosis (Cotton-Meyer grades I and II). However, in severe cases (grades III and IV), endoscopic dilatation alone is unlikely to provide adequate relief of airway obstruction.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option D. Laser excision may be used as part of the surgical management of congenital subglottic stenosis, particularly for cases with focal stenosis or scar tissue. However, in severe cases (grades III and IV), laser excision alone is unlikely to be sufficient, and more extensive surgical procedures such as laryngotracheal reconstruction are typically required.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize congenital subglottic stenosis as a cause of stridor and respiratory distress in newborns, understand the criteria for diagnosis based on subglottic diameter, and know the initial management approach, which may include tracheostomy for severe cases (grades III and IV) to establish a secure airway pending definitive surgical intervention.

questions.text: What structure lies between the two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle and is a common site for Zenker's diverticulum formation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B: Killian's dehiscence

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cricopharyngeus muscle: The cricopharyngeus muscle is one of the two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle and lies above Killian's dehiscence. It forms the upper part of the esophageal sphincter.
  • • Option A. Cricopharyngeus muscle:
  • • Option C. Thyropharyngeus muscle: The thyropharyngeus muscle is the other part of the inferior constrictor muscle and lies below Killian's dehiscence.
  • • Option C. Thyropharyngeus muscle:
  • • Option D. Superior constrictor muscle: The superior constrictor muscle is a different muscle layer of the pharynx and is not directly related to Killian's dehiscence.
  • • Option D. Superior constrictor muscle:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the anatomical location of Killian's dehiscence and its association with Zenker's diverticulum aids in the diagnosis and management of dysphagia and related conditions.

questions.text: Which anatomical space connects directly to the mediastinum, allowing for potential spread of infections from the pharynx to the mediastinum?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D: Danger space

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Carotid space: The carotid space contains the internal carotid artery, internal jugular vein, and several cranial nerves. Infections in this space can lead to carotid artery rupture or thrombosis, but it does not directly connect to the mediastinum.
  • • Option A. Carotid space:
  • • Option B. Retropharyngeal space: The retropharyngeal space is located behind the pharynx and contains retropharyngeal lymph nodes. Infections in this space can lead to retropharyngeal abscesses but do not directly connect to the mediastinum.
  • • Option B. Retropharyngeal space:
  • • Option C. Pretracheal space: The pretracheal space is located anterior to the trachea and contains the thyroid gland and several lymph nodes. Infections in this space can lead to pretracheal abscesses but do not directly connect to the mediastinum.
  • • Option C. Pretracheal space:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the anatomy and clinical significance of the Danger space, which connects directly to the mediastinum, is essential for recognizing the potential spread of infections from the neck to deeper structures, aiding in the prompt diagnosis and management of severe neck infections.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with hoarseness and difficulty breathing. Laryngoscopy reveals papillomatous lesions in the larynx. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Microlaryngeal surgery with CO2 laser excision

questions.correct_answer: C. Microlaryngeal surgery with CO2 laser excision
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C. Microlaryngeal surgery with CO2 laser excision

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Medical management with IFN alpha-2a may be considered as an adjunctive therapy or in cases where surgical intervention is not feasible. However, it is not typically used as the initial management for juvenile papillomatosis.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B . Observation and reassessment may lead to delays in treatment and potentially worsening respiratory symptoms in cases of juvenile papillomatosis, which often require prompt intervention to alleviate airway obstruction.
  • • Option B
  • • Option D. Cryosurgery may be an option for treating juvenile papillomatosis, but it is less commonly used compared to microlaryngeal surgery with CO2 laser excision, which is the preferred initial management approach.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize juvenile papillomatosis as the most common benign tumor of the larynx in children, understand the typical presentation and causative agent (HPV 6 & 11), and know that initial management often involves microlaryngeal surgery with CO2 laser excision to remove papillomatous lesions.

questions.text: Which structure lies 1cm posterior to the end of the middle turbinate and serves as the most common site of origin for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C: Sphenopalatine foramen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Torus tubarius: The torus tubarius is an elevation in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx that contains the opening of the Eustachian tube. It is not the site of origin for JNA.
  • • Option A. Torus tubarius:
  • • Option B. Fossa of Rosenmuller: The fossa of Rosenmuller, located behind the torus tubarius, is the most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma, not JNA.
  • • Option B. Fossa of Rosenmuller:
  • • Option D. Pterygopalatine fossa: The pterygopalatine fossa is a space adjacent to the nasal cavity that contains important structures such as the pterygopalatine ganglion and the branches of the maxillary artery. While JNA arises adjacent to the pterygopalatine fossa, it originates specifically from the branches of the sphenopalatine artery within the fossa.
  • • Option D. Pterygopalatine fossa:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the anatomical location of the sphenopalatine foramen as the most common site of origin for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is essential for recognizing and managing this locally aggressive tumor in clinical practice.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with a history of smoking and alcohol consumption. He complains of hoarseness of voice. Biopsy of a lesion in his larynx confirms squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following statements regarding laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The incidence is highest in the subglottis compared to the glottis and supraglottis.

options.label: B
options.text: MRI is the preferred imaging modality for assessing the extent of the lesion and planning surgery.

options.label: C
options.text: HPV infections are not a significant risk factor for the development of laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma.

options.label: D
options.text: Hoarseness of voice is an uncommon presenting symptom of laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.correct_answer: B. MRI is the preferred imaging modality for assessing the extent of the lesion and planning surgery.
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B. MRI is the preferred imaging modality for assessing the extent of the lesion and planning surgery.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. This statement is incorrect. The glottis has the highest incidence of squamous cell carcinoma compared to the supraglottis and subglottis.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option C. HPV infections are indeed a significant risk factor for the development of laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma, especially in younger patients.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Hoarseness of voice is a common presenting symptom of laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma due to involvement of the vocal cords.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the risk factors, common presentation, and diagnostic approach to laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma, including the role of biopsy and imaging modalities such as CT and MRI in diagnosis and surgical planning.

questions.text: Which anatomical structure forms a circular ridge of muscular fibers at the junction of the nasopharynx and oropharynx, preventing food entry into the nasopharynx during swallowing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C: Passavant’s ridge

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Torus tubarius: The torus tubarius is an elevation in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx that contains the opening of the Eustachian tube. It is not involved in preventing food entry into the nasopharynx during swallowing.
  • • Option A. Torus tubarius:
  • • Option B. Fossa of Rosenmuller: The fossa of Rosenmuller, located behind the torus tubarius, is the most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It is not directly involved in preventing food entry into the nasopharynx.
  • • Option B. Fossa of Rosenmuller:
  • • Option D. Sphenopalatine foramen: The sphenopalatine foramen is an opening located in the lateral wall of the nasal cavity, connecting it to the pterygopalatine fossa. It is not involved in preventing food entry into the nasopharynx during swallowing.
  • • Option D. Sphenopalatine foramen:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the anatomy and function of Passavant’s ridge is crucial for recognizing its role in preventing food entry into the nasopharynx during swallowing, which helps maintain proper swallowing function and prevents nasopharyngeal regurgitation of food.

questions.text: Which organism is the primary causative agent of oral Candidiasis (Moniliasis), and what are the two forms it can manifest as?

options.label: A
options.text: Streptococcus mutans – forms include acute and chronic

options.label: B
options.text: Candida albicans – forms include thrush and chronic hypertrophic candidiasis

options.label: C
options.text: Staphylococcus aureus – forms include pseudomembranous and erythematous

options.label: D
options.text: Haemophilus influenzae – forms include pseudomembranous and granulomatous

questions.correct_answer: B. Candida albicans – forms include thrush and chronic hypertrophic candidiasis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B: Candida albicans – forms include thrush and chronic hypertrophic candidiasis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Oral candidiasis, also known as Moniliasis, is primarily caused by the fungus Candida albicans. It can manifest in two main forms:
  • • 1. Thrush: This form presents as whitish patches on the oral mucosa and tongue, with underlying congested mucosa. Thrush is commonly seen in infants who are not adequately sterilized feeding bottles or maintain proper hygiene. It can also occur in adults with conditions such as diabetes or malignancies.
  • • 1. Thrush:
  • • 2. Chronic hypertrophic candidiasis: In this form, the white patches cannot be easily removed and are termed candida leukoplakia. It represents a chronic and persistent form of oral candidiasis.
  • • 2. Chronic hypertrophic candidiasis:
  • • Treatment for oral candidiasis typically involves antifungal agents such as clotrimazole, which can be administered orally or applied topically to the affected area.
  • • Option A. Streptococcus mutans: Streptococcus mutans is primarily associated with dental caries (tooth decay) rather than oral candidiasis. It does not manifest in the forms described for oral candidiasis.
  • • Option A. Streptococcus mutans:
  • • Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus can cause various infections, but it is not a primary causative agent of oral candidiasis. Its forms include pseudomembranous and erythematous, which are different from the manifestations of oral candidiasis.
  • • Option C. Staphylococcus aureus:
  • • Option D. Haemophilus influenzae: Haemophilus influenzae can cause respiratory tract infections, but it is not associated with oral candidiasis. Its forms include pseudomembranous and granulomatous, which are distinct from the forms of oral candidiasis described.
  • • Option D. Haemophilus influenzae:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oral Candidiasis, primarily caused by Candida albicans, can manifest as thrush, characterized by whitish patches, and chronic hypertrophic candidiasis, presenting as persistent white patches termed candida leukoplakia. Treatment involves antifungal agents such as clotrimazole.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a history of smoking and complains of a recent change in his voice. Laryngoscopy reveals a lesion involving the vocal cords. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following statements regarding glottic carcinoma is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The prognosis is poor due to extensive lymphatic metastasis.

options.label: B
options.text: Early diagnosis is challenging due to the absence of symptoms.

options.label: C
options.text: Vocal cord involvement typically leads to dysphagia as the presenting symptom.

options.label: D
options.text: As there are fewer lymphatics in the glottis, metastasis is less common, leading to a better prognosis.

questions.correct_answer: D. As there are fewer lymphatics in the glottis, metastasis is less common, leading to a better prognosis.
questions.explanation:
Ans.  D. As there are fewer lymphatics in the glottis, metastasis is less common, leading to a better prognosis.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. This statement is incorrect. Prognosis is generally better in glottic carcinoma due to fewer lymphatics, resulting in less common metastasis.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Glottic carcinoma typically presents with changes in voice (dysphonia), facilitating early diagnosis.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Dysphagia is not a typical presenting symptom of glottic carcinoma; rather, it is more commonly associated with supraglottic carcinoma.
  • • Option C.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the typical presentation, diagnosis, and prognosis of glottic carcinoma, including the importance of changes in voice (dysphonia) as an early symptom and the role of laryngoscopy and biopsy in diagnosis.

questions.text: What are the most common ulcers of the oral cavity, characterized by multiple lesions with central necrotic bases surrounded by a red halo, often associated with recurrence?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C: Aphthous ulcers

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Herpes simplex ulcers: Herpes simplex ulcers are caused by the herpes simplex virus and present as painful vesicular lesions that eventually rupture to form ulcers. They are characterized by single or clustered lesions and are typically associated with systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise.
  • • Option A. Herpes simplex ulcers:
  • • Option B. Traumatic ulcers: Traumatic ulcers result from physical injury or trauma to the oral mucosa, such as biting the cheek or tongue, dental procedures, or ill-fitting dental appliances. They are often solitary and do not recur unless the trauma is repeated.
  • • Option B. Traumatic ulcers:
  • • Option D. Candidiasis ulcers: Candidiasis ulcers, caused by Candida albicans fungus, present as white patches or plaques that can be wiped away, leaving a raw, erythematous base. They are commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals and are not typically associated with recurrence.
  • • Option D. Candidiasis ulcers:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aphthous ulcers, characterized by multiple lesions with central necrotic bases surrounded by a red halo, are the most common ulcers of the oral cavity, often associated with recurrence.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with a history of progressive hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Laryngoscopy reveals a T3 lesion involving the pre-epiglottic space and fixed vocal cords. Based on TNM staging, what is the appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.  Chemoradiation.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Radiotherapy alone is typically indicated for Stage I or II laryngeal carcinoma, which have less extensive involvement than Stage III.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option C. Total laryngectomy followed by radiotherapy is usually reserved for advanced cases, such as Stage IVa laryngeal carcinoma involving the thyroid cartilage (T4a).
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Palliative radiotherapy is generally indicated for Stage IVb or IVc laryngeal carcinoma, where curative treatment options may not be feasible due to extensive disease or distant metastasis.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the TNM staging system for laryngeal carcinoma and its implications for treatment decisions, including the appropriate management based on the stage of the disease.

questions.text: A patient presents with restricted tongue movement and speech defects due to forward attachment of the frenulum below the tongue. Which condition is most likely causing these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D: Ankyloglossia (Tongue-tie)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Lingual frenulum hypertrophy: Lingual frenulum hypertrophy refers to an enlarged or thickened lingual frenulum. While this condition may also affect tongue movement, it is not specifically characterized by a forward attachment of the frenulum and is not commonly associated with speech defects.
  • • Option A. Lingual frenulum hypertrophy:
  • • Option B. Torus mandibularis: Torus mandibularis is a bony growth that typically occurs along the lingual surface of the mandible. It does not affect tongue movement or speech and is not related to ankyloglossia.
  • • Option B. Torus mandibularis:
  • • Option C. Macroglossia: Macroglossia refers to an abnormally large tongue, which can impair speech and cause other functional issues. However, it is not caused by a forward attachment of the lingual frenulum, as seen in ankyloglossia.
  • • Option C. Macroglossia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ankyloglossia (Tongue-tie) is characterized by restricted tongue movement due to a forward attachment of the frenulum below the tongue, leading to speech defects, with surgical release being the recommended treatment.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male underwent total laryngectomy for advanced laryngeal carcinoma. Which of the following techniques is most effective for speech rehabilitation in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B. Tracheo-oesophageal speech.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Oesophageal speech involves teaching the patient to swallow air and then release it to produce speech. While it can be effective for some patients, tracheo-oesophageal speech is generally considered more reliable and easier to learn.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option C. Electrolarynx involves the use of an external device held against the skin of the neck, which produces vibrations to create speech. While it can provide a means of communication, tracheo-oesophageal speech is typically preferred for its more natural and intelligible speech output.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Vocal cord implantation is not a commonly used technique for speech rehabilitation after total laryngectomy. It involves the surgical placement of artificial vocal cords, which may not be as effective or practical as tracheo-oesophageal speech.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the various techniques for speech rehabilitation after total laryngectomy, with tracheo-oesophageal speech being the most effective method using artificial prostheses.

questions.text: A patient presents with difficulty in mouth opening (trismus) and a pale whitish appearance of the oral mucosa with fibrotic strands. Which condition is most likely causing these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B: Oral submucous fibrosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Oral leukoplakia: Oral leukoplakia presents as white patches or plaques on the oral mucosa, but it is not specifically characterized by fibrotic strands or trismus. It is commonly associated with tobacco use and carries a risk of malignant transformation.
  • • Option A. Oral leukoplakia:
  • • Option C. Oral lichen planus: Oral lichen planus is characterized by white, lacy patches or erosions on the oral mucosa, along with other features such as Wickham's striae. Trismus is not a typical feature of oral lichen planus.
  • • Option C. Oral lichen planus:
  • • Option D. Oral squamous cell carcinoma: Oral squamous cell carcinoma presents as a non-healing ulcer or mass in the oral cavity. While it may cause trismus as a late-stage complication, it typically does not present with visible fibrotic strands or a pale whitish appearance of the oral mucosa as seen in oral submucous fibrosis.
  • • Option D. Oral squamous cell carcinoma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oral submucous fibrosis is characterized by excessive collagen deposition in the submucosal tissue of the oral cavity, leading to a pale whitish appearance of the mucosa with fibrotic strands and trismus.

questions.text: A patient presents with a cystic, bluish, translucent swelling in the floor of the mouth, just lateral to the frenulum, which pushes the tongue upward. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B: Ranula

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Branchial cleft cyst: Branchial cleft cysts typically present as cystic swellings along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. They result from the persistence of remnants of the branchial apparatus and are not typically located in the floor of the mouth.
  • • Option A. Branchial cleft cyst:
  • • Option C. Thyroglossal duct cyst: Thyroglossal duct cysts are midline cystic swellings that arise due to the persistence of remnants of the thyroglossal duct. They are usually located below the hyoid bone and may move with swallowing or tongue protrusion, distinguishing them from ranulas.
  • • Option C. Thyroglossal duct cyst:
  • • Option D. Parotid duct stone: A parotid duct stone may cause swelling and pain in the parotid gland area but would not typically present as a bluish, translucent swelling in the floor of the mouth as described for a ranula.
  • • Option D. Parotid duct stone:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A ranula is a cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth, lateral to the frenulum, caused by obstruction of ducts in the sublingual gland, and may require surgical excision or marsupialization for treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding tracheostomy is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: High tracheostomy is typically performed at the level of the 5th to 6th tracheal rings.

options.label: B
options.text: Vertical incision is preferred for elective tracheostomy procedures.

options.label: C
options.text: Tracheostomy bypasses the upper airway structures from the nose to the larynx.

options.label: D
options.text: Removal of the tracheostomy tube is known as intubation.

questions.correct_answer: C. Tracheostomy bypasses the upper airway structures from the nose to the larynx.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Tracheostomy bypasses the upper airway structures from the nose to the larynx.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. High tracheostomy is typically performed at the level of the 1st to 2nd tracheal rings, not the 5th to 6th.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. In emergency tracheostomy, a vertical incision may be made, but in elective cases, a horizontal incision is preferred due to better cosmetic outcomes.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option D. Removal of the tracheostomy tube is called decannulation, not intubation.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the purpose and technique of tracheostomy, which involves creating an alternative airway that bypasses the upper airway structures from the nose to the larynx.

questions.text: A patient presents with a white patch in the oral cavity. What is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B: Biopsy of the lesion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Immediate surgical excision: Immediate surgical excision is not the initial step in management of a white patch in the oral cavity. Surgery may be considered after the diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy, particularly if the lesion is suspicious for malignancy.
  • • Option A. Immediate surgical excision:
  • • Option C. Topical antifungal therapy: Topical antifungal therapy may be appropriate if the white patch is confirmed to be caused by candidiasis. However, without a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis, it is not appropriate to initiate antifungal therapy as the initial step.
  • • Option C. Topical antifungal therapy:
  • • Option D. Observation and regular follow-up: Observation and regular follow-up may be appropriate after the diagnosis of leukoplakia or another condition is confirmed. However, the initial step should involve obtaining a biopsy to accurately diagnose the lesion.
  • • Option D. Observation and regular follow-up:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a white patch is observed in the oral cavity clinically, the most appropriate initial step in management is to perform a biopsy of the lesion to confirm the diagnosis, as various conditions such as leukoplakia, lichen planus, and candidiasis can present with similar white lesions.

questions.text: Which anatomical structure connects the lacrimal sac with the nasal cavity and is guarded by the Hasner valve?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Nasolacrimal duct.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The inferior turbinate is a separate bone within the nasal cavity and is involved in the humidification of inspired air but is not associated with the nasolacrimal duct.
  • • Option A. The inferior turbinate
  • • Option B. The inferior meatus is an anatomical region within the nasal cavity where the nasolacrimal duct opens but is not the structure that connects the lacrimal sac with the nasal cavity.
  • • Option B. The inferior meatus
  • • Option D. The medial canthal ligament is involved in the lacrimal pump mechanism but is not directly associated with the nasolacrimal duct.
  • • Option D. The medial canthal ligament

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the anatomy and function of the nasolacrimal duct, including its connection between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity, and its role in tear drainage.

questions.text: A patient presents with bilateral parotid swelling, fever, anorexia, and body aches. Lab results show elevated serum and urinary amylase levels along with the presence of serum IgM and IgG antibodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C: Mumps (viral parotitis)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option.A. Bacterial parotitis: Bacterial parotitis typically presents unilaterally and is characterized by severe pain and tenderness in the affected gland. Unlike mumps, it does not typically present with systemic symptoms such as fever and body aches.
  • • Option.A. Bacterial parotitis:
  • • Option B.Sialolithiasis: Sialolithiasis, or the presence of salivary gland stones, presents with unilateral parotid swelling and pain, often aggravated by meals. It does not typically present with systemic symptoms or elevated amylase levels.
  • • Option B.Sialolithiasis:
  • • Option D. Sjögren's syndrome: Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth (sicca syndrome), along with systemic symptoms such as fatigue and joint pain. While it can affect the salivary glands, it does not typically present with acute parotid swelling or elevated amylase levels.
  • • Option D. Sjögren's syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mumps (viral parotitis) presents with bilateral parotid swelling, fever, anorexia, and body aches, along with elevated serum and urinary amylase levels and the presence of serum IgM and IgG antibodies, aiding in diag

questions.text: A patient presents with pain while eating, along with temporary swelling of the submandibular gland during meals. Palpation reveals a palpable mass in the floor of the mouth. Which condition is most likely causing these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option. A. Mumps (viral parotitis): Mumps typically presents with bilateral parotid swelling along with fever, anorexia, and body aches. It does not typically cause pain or swelling in the floor of the mouth.
  • • Option. A. Mumps (viral parotitis):
  • • Option. B. Sjögren's syndrome: Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth (sicca syndrome), along with systemic symptoms such as fatigue and joint pain. While it can affect the salivary glands, it does not typically cause the formation of salivary gland stones or the associated symptoms described in the question.
  • • Option. B. Sjögren's syndrome:
  • • Option.D. Ranula: Ranula is a cystic swelling arising in the floor of the mouth, typically due to obstruction of the sublingual gland ducts. While it can cause swelling in the floor of the mouth, it is not associated with pain while eating or the presence of palpable masses suggestive of sialolithiasis.
  • • Option.D. Ranula:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sialolithiasis commonly affects the submandibular gland, causing pain while eating, temporary swelling of the gland during meals, and a palpable mass in the floor of the mouth. Diagnosis may require imaging studies such as ultrasound or sialography

questions.text: Which part of the middle turbinate attaches to the lamina papyracea laterally and separates the anterior ethmoid cells from the posterior ethmoid cells?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Second part.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The first part of the middle turbinate attaches to the cribriform plate above and does not separate the anterior and posterior ethmoid cells.
  • • Option A. The first part
  • • Option C. The third part of the middle turbinate attaches to the lamina papyracea and runs horizontally towards the posterior choana, but it does not separate the anterior and posterior ethmoid cells.
  • • Option C. The third part
  • • Option D. The atrium is a shallow depression in front of the middle turbinate attachment and is not directly involved in separating the anterior and posterior ethmoid cells.
  • • Option D. The atrium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the anatomical features of the middle turbinate, particularly the second part, which attaches to the lamina papyracea laterally and divides the ethmoid sinus into anterior and posterior compartments.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a gradually increasing, firm swelling in the tail of the parotid gland. Histological examination reveals both epithelial and mesenchymal elements. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B: Pleomorphic adenoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option.A. Sialolithiasis: Sialolithiasis refers to the presence of salivary gland stones, typically causing pain and swelling in the gland, particularly during meals. It does not present as a gradually increasing firm swelling in a specific location within the parotid gland, nor does it exhibit epithelial and mesenchymal elements on histological examination.
  • • Option.A. Sialolithiasis:
  • • Option.C. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the salivary glands that can also occur in the parotid gland. It typically presents with a mass in the gland and may exhibit cystic, mucinous, and epidermoid components on histological examination. Unlike pleomorphic adenoma, mucoepidermoid carcinoma is malignant and requires more aggressive treatment modalities.
  • • Option.C. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma:
  • • Option.D. Warthin tumor: Warthin tumor, also known as papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, is a benign salivary gland tumor most commonly found in the parotid gland. It typically presents as a painless, slowly growing mass, often in the tail of the parotid gland. Histologically, it is characterized by cystic spaces lined by epithelial cells with lymphoid stroma. However, it does not typically exhibit mesenchymal elements as seen in pleomorphic adenoma.
  • • Option.D. Warthin tumor:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pleomorphic adenoma, the most common benign tumor of the salivary glands, often presents as a gradually increasing, firm swelling in the parotid gland, with histological examination revealing both epithelial and mesenchymal elements. Treatment involves surgical excision, typically in the form of a superficial parotidectomy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a slowly growing mass in the parotid gland. Histological examination reveals the presence of both mucin-producing cells and squamous cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option.A. Pleomorphic adenoma: Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the salivary glands, characterized by a mixture of epithelial and mesenchymal elements. Histologically, it does not typically exhibit mucin-producing cells or squamous cells. It presents as a gradually increasing firm swelling, usually in the tail of the parotid gland.
  • • Option.A. Pleomorphic adenoma:
  • • Option. B. Sialolithiasis: Sialolithiasis refers to the presence of salivary gland stones, which can cause pain and swelling in the affected gland but do not typically exhibit mucin-producing or squamous cells on histological examination. The presentation is usually with acute or recurrent episodes of pain and swelling, particularly during meals.
  • • Option. B. Sialolithiasis:
  • • Option.D. Warthin tumor: Warthin tumor, also known as papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, is a benign salivary gland tumor characterized by cystic spaces lined by epithelial cells with lymphoid stroma. It does not typically exhibit mucin-producing cells or squamous cells on histological examination. It presents as a painless, slowly growing mass, often in the tail of the parotid gland.
  • • Option.D. Warthin tumor:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the salivary glands characterized by the presence of both mucin-producing cells and squamous cells on histological examination. These tumors can invade adjacent structures, and treatment involves surgical excision, with the extent of surgery depending on the grade and stage of the tumor.

questions.text: Which structure serves as a landmark for the opening of the sphenoid ostium?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Superior turbinate.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. The superior meatus is a region within the nasal cavity where the posterior ethmoid air cells open, but it is not specifically associated with the sphenoid ostium.
  • • Option B. The superior meatus
  • • Option C. The Onodi cell is a variant pneumatization of the sphenoid sinus that extends into the posterior ethmoid cells. While it lies close to the optic nerve, it is not a landmark for the sphenoid ostium.
  • • Option C. The Onodi cell
  • • Option D. The sphenoethmoidal recess is the space where the sphenoid sinus opens, but it is not itself a landmark for the opening of the sphenoid ostium.
  • • Option D. The sphenoethmoidal recess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the anatomical landmarks within the nasal cavity, particularly the role of the superior turbinate as a reference point for the opening of the sphenoid ostium.

questions.text: What is the recommended timeframe for reduction of nasal fractures to prevent complications such as callus formation and bone remodeling?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Within 7-10 days of injury.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Within 24 hours of injury: While early reduction may be beneficial in some cases, waiting for the initial edema to resolve before performing reduction is generally preferred.
  • • Option A. Within 24 hours of injury:
  • • Option B. Within 48 hours of injury: Waiting for 7-10 days allows for better visualization and reduction, compared to performing reduction within 48 hours.
  • • Option B. Within 48 hours of injury:
  • • Option D. Within 3 months of injury: Delaying reduction beyond 7-10 days can lead to difficulties in reduction due to callus formation and bone remodeling, and may necessitate open septo-rhinoplasty after 3 months.
  • • Option D. Within 3 months of injury:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the optimal timeframe for reducing nasal fractures to minimize complications such as callus formation and bone remodeling.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for septal hematoma to prevent complications?
questions.explanation:
Ans.is C) Incision and drainage.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Observation and follow-up: Septal hematoma requires immediate intervention to prevent complications; observation without treatment can lead to serious consequences.
  • • Option A. Observation and follow-up:
  • • Option B. Intravenous antibiotics: While antibiotics are part of the treatment, incision and drainage are the primary interventions to evacuate the hematoma and prevent complications.
  • • Option B. Intravenous antibiotics:
  • • Option D. Nasal decongestants: Nasal decongestants may help relieve symptoms but do not address the underlying hematoma and are not the primary treatment for septal hematoma.
  • • Option D. Nasal decongestants:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognizing the importance of prompt incision and drainage as the initial treatment for septal hematoma to prevent complications such as fibrous change and secondary infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate management option for a large septal perforation causing dryness and crusting?

options.label: D
options.text: Free grafts or pedicled flaps reconstruction

questions.correct_answer: D. Free grafts or pedicled flaps reconstruction
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Free grafts or pedicled flaps reconstruction.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Enlargement of the perforation: Enlarging the perforation is not an appropriate management option for large septal perforations causing dryness and crusting, as it may exacerbate symptoms by increasing airflow and crusting.
  • • Option A. Enlargement of the perforation:
  • • Option B. Nasal decongestants: Nasal decongestants may help relieve symptoms of nasal congestion but do not address the underlying cause of the perforation or the associated dryness and crusting.
  • • Option B. Nasal decongestants:
  • • Option C. Topical corticosteroids: Topical corticosteroids may help reduce inflammation and crusting associated with septal perforation but are typically used as adjunctive therapy rather than a primary management option for large perforations requiring surgical closure.
  • • Option C. Topical corticosteroids:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognizing the appropriate management approach for large septal perforations causing dryness and crusting, which involves surgical closure using free grafts or pedicled flaps reconstruction to restore nasal integrity and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following vascular structures is commonly associated with epistaxis in children and young adults?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.  Sphenopalatine artery.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Inferior turbinate artery: While the inferior turbinate artery contributes to the blood supply of the nasal cavity, it is not typically associated with epistaxis in children and young adults.
  • • Option A. Inferior turbinate artery:
  • • Option C. Posterior ethmoidal artery: The posterior ethmoidal artery supplies the posterior part of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses but is less commonly involved in epistaxis compared to the sphenopalatine artery.
  • • Option C. Posterior ethmoidal artery:
  • • Option D. Greater palatine artery: The greater palatine artery supplies the hard palate and adjacent structures but is not typically associated with epistaxis in children and young adults.
  • • Option D. Greater palatine artery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identifying the sphenopalatine artery as the major contributor to Little's area and the common cause of epistaxis in children and young adults.

questions.text: A patient presents with profuse epistaxis that is unresponsive to initial measures such as Trotter's method and chemical cauterization. What is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.correct_answer: B. Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL).

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Posterior nasal packing: While posterior nasal packing may be considered if bleeding persists after anterior packing, TESPAL is a more targeted approach that addresses the source of bleeding.
  • • Option A. Posterior nasal packing:
  • • Option C. External carotid artery ligation: This intervention is typically reserved for extreme cases of refractory epistaxis after other measures have failed, and it involves ligating the external carotid artery. TESPAL is a more conservative approach before resorting to more invasive procedures like external carotid artery ligation.
  • • Option C. External carotid artery ligation:
  • • Option D. Anterior nasal packing: While anterior nasal packing is an initial intervention for epistaxis, if bleeding persists despite packing, TESPAL may be a more effective option.
  • • Option D. Anterior nasal packing:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of refractory epistaxis unresponsive to initial measures, understanding the appropriate sequence of management options, including TESPAL as a minimally invasive technique targeting the sphenopalatine artery, is crucial for effective patient care.

questions.text: A patient present with a complaint of perceiving a bad smell that is not present in their environment. Which of the following terms best describes this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Cacosmia.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hyposmia: Hyposmia refers to a decreased sensation of smell. It is characterized by a reduced ability to detect odors, but it does not necessarily involve perceiving unpleasant smells.
  • • Option A. Hyposmia:
  • • Option B. Anosmia: Anosmia is the complete absence of the sense of smell. Individuals with anosmia cannot detect any odors, including both pleasant and unpleasant smells.
  • • Option B. Anosmia:
  • • Option D. Parosmia: Parosmia refers to a perverted sensation of smell where one kind of smell is perceived as another. For example, a pleasant smell may be perceived as unpleasant or vice versa.
  • • Option D. Parosmia:
  • • In this case, the patient is experiencing the perception of a bad smell that is not present, indicating cacosmia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the different types of olfactory disorders, including cacosmia, and their characteristic features is essential for diagnosing and managing patients with complaints related to smell perception.

questions.text: A patient presents with chronic foul-smelling nasal discharge and anosmia. Examination reveals pale nasal mucosa with excessive crusting and widened nasal cavities. Which of the following terms best describes the condition associated with these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Atrophic rhinitis.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Allergic rhinitis: Allergic rhinitis is characterized by symptoms such as sneezing, itching, nasal congestion, and clear nasal discharge, often triggered by allergens such as pollen, dust mites, or animal dander. It is not typically associated with foul-smelling discharge or nasal mucosal atrophy.
  • • Option A. Allergic rhinitis:
  • • Option B. Nasal polyposis: Nasal polyposis refers to the presence of benign growths (polyps) in the nasal cavity or paranasal sinuses. While nasal polyps can cause nasal obstruction and sometimes anosmia, they are not typically associated with pale nasal mucosa or excessive crusting.
  • • Option B. Nasal polyposis:
  • • Option D. Rhinoscleroma: Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It is characterized by the formation of nodules and fibrous tissue in the nasal cavity and may lead to nasal obstruction and a foul-smelling discharge. However, it is distinct from atrophic rhinitis, which is characterized by mucosal atrophy and excessive crusting.
  • • Option D. Rhinoscleroma:
  • • In this case, the patient's presentation, including chronic foul-smelling discharge, anosmia, pale mucosa, and excessive crusting, is consistent with atrophic rhinitis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrophic rhinitis, characterized by pale nasal mucosa, foul-smelling discharge, and anosmia, is associated with atrophy of the nasal mucosa and can lead to complications such as nasal obstruction and secondary infections.

questions.text: A patient present with watery nasal discharge, sneezing, nasal obstruction, and itching. On examination, the patient has a transverse nasal crease, dark circles under the eyes, and creases in the lower eyelid skin. Laboratory tests show elevated absolute eosinophil count and serum IgE levels. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.  Allergic rhinitis.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Atrophic rhinitis: Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by nasal mucosal atrophy, pale mucosa, and foul-smelling nasal discharge. It is not typically associated with elevated eosinophil count or serum IgE levels.
  • • Option A. Atrophic rhinitis:
  • • Option B. Rhinoscleroma: Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It typically presents with nasal obstruction and may lead to a foul-smelling discharge but is not associated with allergic symptoms or elevated IgE levels.
  • • Option B. Rhinoscleroma:
  • • Option D. Vasomotor rhinitis: Vasomotor rhinitis is characterized by nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and postnasal drip, often triggered by environmental factors such as changes in temperature, humidity, or air pollution. It is not typically associated with allergic symptoms or elevated IgE levels.
  • • Option D. Vasomotor rhinitis:
  • • In this case, the patient's presentation, including symptoms of allergic rhinitis, allergic signs such as allergic salute and allergic shiners, and laboratory findings of elevated eosinophil count and serum IgE levels, are consistent with allergic rhinitis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allergic rhinitis, characterized by symptoms such as watery nasal discharge, sneezing, nasal obstruction, and itching, is associated with elevated serum IgE levels and eosinophil count, along with signs such as allergic salute and allergic shiners.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms similar to allergic rhinitis, including nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and postnasal drip. However, allergic testing results are negative. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Vasomotor rhinitis.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by nasal mucosal atrophy and a foul-smelling nasal discharge. It is not typically associated with symptoms resembling allergic rhinitis or negative allergic testing results.
  • • Option A. Atrophic rhinitis
  • • Option B) Rhinoscleroma: Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It presents with nasal obstruction and may lead to a foul-smelling discharge but is not typically associated with symptoms resembling allergic rhinitis or negative allergic testing results.
  • • Option B) Rhinoscleroma:
  • • Option C. Allergic rhinitis: Allergic rhinitis is characterized by an IgE-mediated immune response to airborne allergens, resulting in symptoms such as watery nasal discharge, sneezing, nasal obstruction, and itching. However, allergic testing results are typically positive in allergic rhinitis.
  • • Option C. Allergic rhinitis:
  • • In this case, the patient's presentation of symptoms resembling allergic rhinitis with negative allergic testing results is consistent with vasomotor rhinitis, which is characterized by autonomic imbalance and parasympathetic overactivity.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vasomotor rhinitis presents with symptoms similar to allergic rhinitis but is characterized by negative allergic testing results due to autonomic imbalance causing parasympathetic overactivity, leading to nasal mucosal vasodilation. Treatment options include avoidance of triggers and medications such as antihistamines, decongestants, steroids, and tranquilizers.

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal symptoms characterized by purulent discharge and crusting, followed by painless nodules subdermally giving a woody feel to the nose. Biopsy of the nasal mucosa reveals plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells, and Russell bodies. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Rhinoscleroma.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Allergic rhinitis: Allergic rhinitis is characterized by an IgE-mediated immune response to airborne allergens, resulting in symptoms such as watery nasal discharge, sneezing, nasal obstruction, and itching. It is not associated with the chronic granulomatous infection seen in rhinoscleroma.
  • • Option A. Allergic rhinitis:
  • • Option B. Atrophic rhinitis: Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by nasal mucosal atrophy and a foul-smelling nasal discharge. While both rhinoscleroma and atrophic rhinitis may present with nasal crusting, the clinical features and histopathological findings described are more consistent with rhinoscleroma.
  • • Option B. Atrophic rhinitis:
  • • Option D. Vasomotor rhinitis: Vasomotor rhinitis is characterized by symptoms similar to allergic rhinitis but with negative allergic testing results. It is not associated with the chronic granulomatous infection seen in rhinoscleroma.
