  • • Option D. Vasomotor rhinitis:
  • • In this case, the patient's presentation of chronic nasal symptoms with characteristic nodules and histopathological findings is consistent with rhinoscleroma.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, characterized by purulent discharge, woody nodules in the nose, and histopathological findings of plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells, and Russell bodies. Treatment includes antibiotics and surgical intervention for stenosis repair.

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal symptoms characterized by blood-tinged discharge and stuffiness. On examination, a leafy, polypoidal mass with a pink to purple appearance is noted, which bleeds upon touch. Biopsy reveals spores bursting through the chitinous wall of sporangia. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Rhinosporidiosis.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Allergic rhinitis: Allergic rhinitis is characterized by an IgE-mediated immune response to airborne allergens, resulting in symptoms such as watery nasal discharge, sneezing, nasal obstruction, and itching. It does not typically present with the characteristic findings described for rhinosporidiosis.
  • • Option A. Allergic rhinitis:
  • • Option C. Vasomotor rhinitis: Vasomotor rhinitis is characterized by symptoms similar to allergic rhinitis but with negative allergic testing results. It is not associated with the chronic infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi.
  • • Option C. Vasomotor rhinitis:
  • • Option D. Atrophic rhinitis: Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by nasal mucosal atrophy and a foul-smelling nasal discharge. It does not present with the characteristic polypoidal masses and bleeding seen in rhinosporidiosis.
  • • Option D. Atrophic rhinitis:
  • • In this case, the patient's presentation of nasal symptoms with characteristic polypoidal masses, bleeding upon touch, and histopathological findings of spores bursting through sporangia is consistent with rhinosporidiosis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, presenting with characteristic leafy, polypoidal masses in the nasal cavity or other mucosal surfaces, pink to purple in color resembling strawberries, and histopathological findings of spores bursting through sporangia. Treatment involves surgical excision and diathermy with base cauterization, along with dapsone therapy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with nasal obstruction, discharge, and intermittent epistaxis. Examination reveals a mass in the middle meatus on the lateral wall of the nose. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of inverted papilloma. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Medial maxillectomy.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The treatment of choice for inverted papilloma is surgical resection. For lesions limited to the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses, endoscopic sinus surgery (option B) may be sufficient. However, if the tumor involves the maxillary sinus extensively or if there is suspicion of malignancy, medial maxillectomy (option C) is preferred. Medial maxillectomy involves removal of the medial wall of the maxillary sinus, providing better access to the tumor and reducing the risk of recurrence.
  • • Intranasal corticosteroid spray (option A) may be used adjunctively for symptom relief in patients with nasal obstruction and discharge but is not curative for inverted papilloma. Radiation therapy (option D) is generally not recommended for the treatment of inverted papilloma due to the risk of recurrence and malignant transformation.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice for inverted papilloma involving the maxillary sinus extensively, providing better access to the tumor and reducing the risk of recurrence.

questions.text: Which sinus is least commonly infected among the paranasal sinuses?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Sphenoid sinus.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Maxillary sinus: It is pyramidal-shaped and the most common sinus to get infected. It is the earliest sinus to develop and is often affected by sinusitis.
  • • Option A. Maxillary sinus:
  • • Option B. Ethmoid sinus: Present in the ethmoidal labyrinth, it divides into anterior and posterior portions by the ground lamella. Ethmoid sinusitis is common in children due to its early pneumatisation and close proximity to the nasal passages.
  • • Option B. Ethmoid sinus:
  • • Option C. Frontal sinus: Opens into the middle meatus through the frontal recess. It is absent at birth and is the last sinus to develop. Osteoma formation is most common in the frontal sinus.
  • • Option C.
  • • Frontal sinus:
  • • Option D. Sphenoid sinus: It is located behind the ethmoid sinus and is the least commonly infected sinus.
  • • Option D. Sphenoid sinus:
  • • Infections of the sphenoid sinus are less frequent compared to other sinuses due to its anatomical location and drainage pathways. However, when sphenoid sinusitis does occur, it can present with nonspecific symptoms and may require careful evaluation and management.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sphenoid sinus is the least commonly infected among the paranasal sinuses.

questions.text: Which sinusitis typically presents with pain in the occipital area or vertex?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Sphenoid sinusitis.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Maxillary sinusitis: Maxillary sinusitis commonly presents with pain or pressure in the cheek area, toothache, and nasal congestion. The ostium of the maxillary sinus is located higher than the floor level, leading to impaired drainage and susceptibility to infection.
  • • Option A. Maxillary sinusitis:
  • • Option B. Ethmoid sinusitis: Ethmoid sinusitis often presents with pain over the root of the nose and deep to the eye. It is common in children and can cause symptoms such as nasal congestion and postnasal drip.
  • • Option B. Ethmoid sinusitis:
  • • Option C. Frontal sinusitis: Frontal sinusitis typically presents with headache, with the pain localized to the frontal area and medial canthus. Headache may be more prominent in the morning and may subside by the evening, a pattern sometimes referred to as periodic or office headache.
  • • Option C. Frontal sinusitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sphenoid sinusitis is characterized by pain in the occipital area or vertex, distinguishing it from other types of sinusitis, which often present with pain in different locations.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about mucormycosis is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is caused by Aspergillus and primarily affects the lungs.

options.label: B
options.text: It is characterized by the formation of white eschars in the nasal cavity.

options.label: C
options.text: It is commonly seen in immunocompetent patients.

options.label: D
options.text: It can cause ischemic necrosis and black eschars, often involving the inferior turbinate, palate, or sinus.

questions.correct_answer: D. It can cause ischemic necrosis and black eschars, often involving the inferior turbinate, palate, or sinus.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D It can cause ischemic necrosis and black eschars, often involving the inferior turbinate, palate, or sinus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. It is caused by Aspergillus and primarily affects the lungs:
  • • Option A. It is caused by Aspergillus and primarily affects the lungs:
  • • This statement is incorrect. Mucormycosis is caused by fungi of the order Mucorales, such as Mucor and Rhizopus species, not Aspergillus. Additionally, mucormycosis primarily affects the sinuses, although it can also involve other sites such as the lungs and brain.
  • • Option B. It is characterized by the formation of white eschars in the nasal cavity:
  • • Option B. It is characterized by the formation of white eschars in the nasal cavity:
  • • This statement is incorrect. Mucormycosis typically presents with black eschars rather than white eschars. White eschars are more commonly associated with infections such as candidiasis.
  • • Option C. It is commonly seen in immunocompetent patients:
  • • Option C. It is commonly seen in immunocompetent patients:
  • • This statement is incorrect. Mucormycosis is more commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, particularly those with conditions such as uncontrolled diabetes, hematological malignancies, or those undergoing immunosuppressive therapy.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucormycosis can cause ischemic necrosis and black eschars, often involving the inferior turbinate, palate, or sinus, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, and prompt diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent life-threatening complications.

questions.text: Which sign helps differentiate between antrochoanal polyp and tumors originating from the pharyngeal wall like angiofibroma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Crescent sign / Dodd sign.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Osseous erosion sig: This sign refers to erosion of the bone and is typically seen in aggressive lesions such as malignancies. It does not specifically differentiate between antrochoanal polyp and tumors originating from the pharyngeal wall.
  • • Option A. Osseous erosion sig:
  • • Option C. Ethmoidal mucosal thickening: Ethmoidal mucosal thickening is a radiological finding commonly seen in conditions such as sinusitis or allergic rhinitis. It is not specific for distinguishing between antrochoanal polyp and tumors originating from the pharyngeal wall.
  • • Option C. Ethmoidal mucosal thickening:
  • • Option D. Ethmoidal air-fluid level: An ethmoidal air-fluid level is indicative of sinusitis with fluid accumulation within the ethmoid sinuses. This finding does not aid in differentiating between antrochoanal polyp and tumors originating from the pharyngeal wall.
  • • Option D. Ethmoidal air-fluid level:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Crescent sign, also known as the Dodd sign, is a radiological finding characterized by a small air column between the posterior nasopharyngeal wall and the antrochoanal polyp, aiding in the differentiation of antrochoanal polyp from tumors originating from the pharyngeal wall like angiofibroma.

questions.text: Which of the following is a sign seen in cases of CSF rhinorrhoea due to trauma but not in cases of non-traumatic CSF rhinorrhoea?

options.label: C
options.text: Double ring sign / target sign / halo sign

questions.correct_answer: C. Double ring sign / target sign / halo sign
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Double ring sign / target sign / halo sign.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Reservoir sign: The reservoir sign refers to the fluid collected in the sinuses during the supine position, particularly in the sphenoid sinus, which empties into the nose and gushes out when the neck is flexed.
  • • Option A. Reservoir sign:
  • • Option B. Handkerchief test: The handkerchief test involves placing a handkerchief beneath the nasal discharge to observe if it stiffens. In CSF rhinorrhoea, the discharge does not stiffen due to the absence of mucus, whereas mucus would stiffen the handkerchief. This is a clinical test, not a sign.
  • • Option B. Handkerchief test:
  • • Option D. Localizing test: The localizing test involves injecting fluorescein intrathecally into the CSF and observing for green coloration of the nasal discharge on nasal endoscopy. This test is used to localize the site of CSF leakage but is not a sign.
  • • Option D. Localizing test:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of CSF rhinorrhoea due to trauma, the characteristic sign seen is the Double ring sign / target sign / halo sign, which consists of a central red spot (blood) surrounded by a peripheral halo (CSF).

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic methods is NOT commonly used for confirming choanal atresia?

options.label: A
options.text: Failure to pass a catheter from nose to pharynx

options.label: C
options.text: Installing radioopaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral film

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Olfactory testing.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Failure to pass a catheter from nose to pharynx: In choanal atresia, the presence of a membrane obstructing the choana prevents the passage of a catheter from the nose to the pharynx. This is a classic diagnostic maneuver used to identify the condition.
  • • Option A. Failure to pass a catheter from nose to pharynx:
  • • Option B. Flexible nasal endoscopy: Flexible nasal endoscopy allows direct visualization of the nasal passages and the choana. It is a valuable tool for confirming the diagnosis of choanal atresia by observing the obstruction at the posterior nasal aperture.
  • • Option B. Flexible nasal endoscopy:
  • • Option C. Installing radioopaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral film: This method involves introducing radioopaque dye into the nose and then obtaining a lateral X-ray film. The presence of the dye in the nasopharynx confirms the diagnosis by demonstrating the obstruction at the level of the choana.
  • • Option C. Installing radioopaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral film:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Choanal atresia is typically diagnosed using methods such as failure to pass a catheter from nose to pharynx, flexible nasal endoscopy, and installing radioopaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral film. Olfactory testing is not commonly used for confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: A newborn presents with a polypoidal mass in the nostril. On examination, the mass is soft, compressible, and transilluminant. The Furstenberg test is positive. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Encephalocele.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Nasal glioma: Nasal glioma is a non-tumorous mass composed of separated brain tissue that lies in the nose. Unlike encephalocele, nasal glioma presents as a firm, non-compressible, and non-transilluminant mass. Additionally, the Furstenberg test is negative in nasal glioma.
  • • Option A. Nasal glioma:
  • • Option B. Nasopharyngeal teratoma: Nasopharyngeal teratoma is a rare tumor composed of multiple tissues such as bone, cartilage, and neural tissue. It typically presents as a solid mass in the nasopharynx, not as a polypoidal mass in the nostril.
  • • Option B. Nasopharyngeal teratoma:
  • • Option C. Choanal atresia: Choanal atresia is a congenital condition characterized by the blockage of the posterior nasal passage (choanae). It typically presents with respiratory distress in newborns, but it does not manifest as a polypoidal mass in the nostril.
  • • Option C. Choanal atresia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Encephalocele presents as a soft, compressible, and transilluminant mass in the nostril of an infant, with a positive Furstenberg test. This condition involves the herniation of brain tissue through a congenital bony defect.

questions.text: A patient presents with periorbital edema, diplopia, and corneal anesthesia. Which complication of sinusitis is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Orbital cellulitis.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Osteomyelitis of the frontal bone: Osteomyelitis of the frontal bone can present as Pot's puffy tumor, characterized by frontal swelling and tenderness. However, it does not typically manifest with periorbital edema, diplopia, or corneal anesthesia.
  • • Option A. Osteomyelitis of the frontal bone:
  • • Option B. Mucocele: Mucocele occurs due to chronic obstruction of sinus openings, leading to cystic dilatation of mucous glands in the sinuses. While mucoceles can cause orbital displacement, they do not typically present with the constellation of symptoms described in the question.
  • • Option B. Mucocele:
  • • Option D. Pyocele: Pyocele is an infection of a mucocele and can lead to similar symptoms as orbital cellulitis, but it specifically denotes an infected cystic dilatation of the sinus mucosa. However, orbital cellulitis is the more common complication associated with sinusitis.
  • • Option D. Pyocele:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orbital cellulitis is a serious complication of sinusitis that can present with periorbital edema, proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and corneal anesthesia due to involvement of the branches of the trigeminal nerve. Diplopia can also occur due to involvement of the extraocular muscles.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with nasal congestion and bilateral nasal polyps. Which condition is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ethmoidal polyposis.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Antrochoanal polyposis: Antrochoanal polyposis is characterized by the presence of a single unilateral polyp arising from the maxillary sinus and extending into the choana. Unlike ethmoidal polyposis, it typically presents with unilateral nasal obstruction.
  • • Option B. Antrochoanal polyposis:
  • • Option C. Frontal sinusitis: Frontal sinusitis primarily affects the frontal sinus and is characterized by symptoms such as frontal headache, fever, and nasal discharge. It is less likely to present with nasal polyps.
  • • Option C. Frontal sinusitis:
  • • Option D. Maxillary sinusitis: Maxillary sinusitis primarily affects the maxillary sinus and is characterized by symptoms such as facial pain or pressure, toothache, and nasal discharge. It is less likely to present with nasal polyps.
  • • Option D. Maxillary sinusitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethmoidal polyposis is characterized by multiple small polyps in the ethmoidal sinuses and is commonly associated with allergic etiology, presenting with bilateral nasal congestion. Antrochoanal polyposis, on the other hand, is characterized by a single unilateral polyp extending into the choana.
